title: red wall tories behind pork
story: The Red Wall Tories behind pork pie plot to oust Boris Johnson from Downing StreetAngry  MPs have been heaping pressure on the Prime Minister as speculation mounts over his futureBoris Johnson is facing calls to resign Image: UK PARLIAMENT AFP via Getty ImagByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Jan | commentsBoris Johnsonaposs political future is hanging in the balance as his own MPs broke cover to call for him to quit over the Downing Street party saga. Angry Red Wall MPs have been heaping pressure on the Prime Minister as Westminster buzzes with rumours over how many letters of no confidence have gone into the Tory backbench  Committee. Only  chairman Sir Graham Brady knows the true number but tensions are running high as Boris Johnson tries to win over his mutinous MPs. Six senior Tories have openly called for Mr Johnson to quit but reports of a Red Wall rebellion are adding to the PMaposs woes. Dubbed the pork pie plot as a meeting was hosted by the Melton MP Alicia Kearns, it underlines the level of anger among some of the  intake.And Bury South MP Christian Wakeford dramatically abandoned the Tories for the Labour Party on Wednesday. Here we look the new rebels making le dficult for Boris Johnson. What is a aposRed Wallapos Tory MP  The term loosely refers to the Conservatives who won their seats off Labour during Boris Johnsonaposs  election landslide. The Red Wall is a nickname for Labouraposs traditional heartlands in England and Wales, particularly seats in the North of England, North Wales and the Midlands . A swathe of these seats turned Tory in , including Tony Blairaposs old seat of Sedgefield, in Co Durham, Blyth Valley in Northumberland and Workington in Cumbria. These MPs were perceived as loyal to Boris Johnson but discontent has been mounting over broken promises on levelling up and rail reform. Partygate has also landed badly with voters, and some of these new MPs may be feeling vulnerable going into the next election. Who are the Pork Pie plotters  Alicia Kearns The former Foreign Office official has been outspoken about the UK’s chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan and the handling of the crisis by senior civil servants. Ms Kearns, , MP for Rutland and Melton has hosted meetings of anti-Johnson plotters - leading to the plan being named after Melton Mowbray’s most famous export. Her , majority in the safe blue East Midlands seat allows her the luxury of plotting.  Dehenna Davison The PM’s then girlfriend and now we Carrie was pictured campaigning with Ms Davison in Bishop Auckland, Co Durham in the run-up to the  ballot. The -year-oldaposs stunning victory was the first time the Tories had won the seat in nearly  years. The arch Brexiteer presents a GB News show with ex-UKIP chief Nigel Farage.  Gary Sambrook The Birmingham Northfield MP is a Covid passport rebel and said the PM must consider his positionhe is found to have broken lockdown laws. As secretary of the  Committee, Mr Sambrook, , would be one of the MPs responsible for running a no-confidence vote and subsequent leadership race. Chris Loder The former train guard, , worked his way up through the industry to become head of new trains for South Western Railway. His majority of , in the Conservative stronghold of West Dorset should make him electorally immune to fury at the PM and Partygate. Christian WakefordThe Bury South MP didnapost attend the meeting but he became the first Red Wall Tory to say publicly that he had submitted a latter of no confidence.Within  hours he had defected to Labour, dramatically joining the party for Prime Ministeraposs Questions on Wednesday.In an excoriating letter to Boris Johnson, he said: Britain needs a Government focused on tackling the cost-of-living crisis and providing a path out of the pandemic that protects living standards and defends the security of all. It needs a Government that upholds the highest standards of integrity and probity in public le and sadly both you and the Conservative Party as a whole have shown themselves incapable of offering the leadership and Government this country deserves.He added: My decision is about much more than your leadership and the disgraceful way you have conducted yourself in recent weeks. news politics sue-grays-report-downing-street-"Boris Johnson denies allegations MPs were blackmailedByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The temperature is rising for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as the jaw-dropping Partygate scandal continues to rage, leaving him facing fury on both sides of the aisle.During Prime Ministeraposs Question on January , the PM faced a relentless barrage of questions about Partygate as discussions of a possible vote of no confidence continue to swirl.The defection of former Conservative MP Christopher Wakeford to the Labour benches just minutes before PMQs was designed to cause carnage to the Tories - but appears to have stopped the Pork Pie Plotters in their tracks. Sir Graham Brady, chair of the all-important  Committee made up of Tory backbenchers, has not yet received the magical  letters that would trigger a vote of no confidence. Political pundits believe many Tories are now awaiting the results of the Gray investigation before deciding whether or not to pull that trigger.  Johnsonaposs alleged contempt for the rules put in place to help prevent the spread of coronavirus over the past two years has caused anger throughout the nation.In response to the frustration - which stems from millions of Brits making huge sacrices, including not being able to be with elderly loved ones - an investigation has been launched into the string of gatherings. At the helm of investigation sits Sue Gray, the most powerful person youaposve never heard of.Who is Sue Gray   Senior civil servant Sue Gray served as Director General of Propriety and Ethics in the Cabinet Office between  and .Before this, she worked in the departments of Transport, Health and Work and Pensions. After these roles, she took a career break in the late s to run a pub in Northern Ireland before joining the Cabinet Office in the s.She now holds the role of the Second Permanent Secretary to the Cabinet Office, a role charged with leading on the Union and the Constitution.When is the Sue Gray report into Downing Street party allegations   The report is now expected to be released no sooner than Monday next week - the exact date remains to be confirmed. PM Johnson confirmed the report is expected next week during his embattled PMQs on January .The reason no one has any hard and fast answers about the reportaposs release date stems from the additional revelations cropping up about more parties alleged to have taken place. What does the Sue Gray investigation cover   The primary purpose of Grayaposs report is, according to the Cabinet Office, to: Establish swtly a general understanding of the nature of the gatherings, including attendance, the setting and the purpose, with reference to adherence to the guidance in place at the time.The scope of the report initially set out to cover the Downing Street Christmas parties on November  and December , but the number of dates under the microscope has now been extended to include two parties that took place on the night before Prince Philipaposs funeral on April . According to the terms of reference set out for the investigation: Where there are credible allegations relating to other gatherings, these may be investigated.They also state that: If required, the investigations will establish whether inidual disciplinary action is warranted. The terms set out that investigators will have access to documents and will be able to speak to staff throughout its course. It is now understood that Grayaposs investigation will now include an interview with Johnsonaposs former aide, Dominic Cummins over the claims he made that that the PM lied to Parliament.Is the Sue Gray investigation independent  One key concern remains, however, about the independence of the investigation. This is because despite being at the heart of Grayaposs explorations, Boris Johnson is also the person who gets to decidethe next stage of the investigation can actually go ahead.After Grayaposs report, Johnson will have the final say as to whether the Prime Minister’s advisor on ministerial interests, Lord Geidt, can actually start an investigation into any breaches of ministerial code.Speaking on the matter, Angela Rayner, the deputy Labour leader, said: “The PM has set the terms of Sue Gray’s probe and he has chosen to exclude the conduct of Ministers from it, creating a neat loophole for himself.“Any judgement on the conduct of Boris Johnson goes to... Boris Johnson. “A farcical circular process from a Prime Minister that will escape responsibility in any way he can. title: voters split over tory mp
story: Bury South voters react to Christian Wakefords defection: We should have a by-electionBury South MP Christian Wakeford has defected to the Labour Party just moments before Boris Johnson arrived in the House of Commons for Prime Ministers Questions Image: Mercury Press  Media Ltd.ByPaul Byrne:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A Conservative MP has defected to the Labour Party, accusing Boris Johnson of being incapable of offering the leadership the country deserves.Bury South MP Christian Wakeford, who was elected in , had been one of seven Tory MPs to publicly express no confidence in the Prime Minister.In a letter, he wrote: You and the Conservative Party as a whole have shown themselves incapable of offering the leadership and government this country deserves.The announcement came just moments before the PM took to the floor for Prime Ministeraposs Questions. Labour leader Keir Starmer said: I would like to welcome Christian Wakeford to the Labour Party. He has always put the people of Bury South first.But Health Secretary Sajid Javid told Sky News: “I feel sorry for the people of Bury South. I think a by-election would be welcome… I think Christian should be happy with a by-election”. He added: “They’ve got an MP who’s changed his affiliation without their permission”. Labour has indicated there will not be a by-election. So what do the voters of Bury South think  We spoke to them.  In the town of Prestwich, which sits in the Bury South constituency, there was a mixed response today to Christian Wakeford’s defection from Tory to Labour. Sham Raja, , said: “It’s so shameful. He signed up to be a Conservative MP. It’s disgraceful, he was elected under the Conservative banner.“There are lots of small businesses struggling at the moment and he’s said nothing about this. Boris Johnson was the only guy to bring us out of Europe and get Brexit done.“I think he should step down as an MP andhe wants to be a Labour MP, he should apply to be one. “He’s not won on a Labour  and he should take it upon himself to step down.” Jeremy Burtles, , said: “There should be another election – you can’t just switch. If you want to change parties, you need to step down. “You always vote for the party you want in charge so I think it’s ridiculous to switch all of a sudden. “If you’re going to change your view, you should just step down.” And Hazel Donnelly, , said: “I don’t think it was very good at all, he shouldn’t be allowed to do that.  “It won’t change the way I vote because I am a Conservative. “I don’t think it’s a big deal what Boris did - there are much worse things that have happened recently. “There should be certain rules with these things. I think he has broken a rule but there are more important things going on at the moment.” But Barry Humphries, , backed the MPaposs decision. He said: “Good for him, I think he’s doing what’s right for him and he’s standing up for what he believes in.” And Ifkan Ahmed, , added: “I’ve always been happy with him. I think these days it’s okay to change your policies. “He has been very good for our area and I’m happy with what he’s done. It doesn’t matter to me that he has changed.”  Vickie Stone, , said: “If he wants to do it because of Boris Johnson then I think that’s fair enough. “If he doesn’t agree with the way Boris is handling the situation then that’s up to him. “I’m more bothered about the leadership, I’m worried about who is going to replace Borisit ends up going that way.” In Radclfe, the centre of the constituency, the MPaposs office, painted in true-blue Tory colours, was shuttered. Outside on the street, ex-Labour and current Tory voter Mavis Leach said: Well, Iaposm surprised. Are there others doing it, as well, getting out of a sinking ship before it goes down  Mrs Leach, who said she disavowed Labour because of a dislike for former leader Jeremy Corbyn, said Boris Johnson should stay on as Prime Minister.I know heaposs done wrong, done a lot of things wrong, she said. Boris has done a lot of things. We know that. But I think heaposs done a good job in other things,bringing the vaccinations in, and weaposre in a good place for that. Another local, Jonathan Boston, a Labour supporter, said Mr Wakefordaposs change in loyalty is really good news. Presumably, itaposs all to do with partygate, he said, referring to allegations of lockdown-busting parties within No , though a Labour spokesman has since said talks with Mr Wakeford began before the scandal hit. Mr Boston said: From what one hears, all the MPs have had millions of emails from constituents saying, aposItaposs terrible and heaposs got to go,apos so I donapost think any Tory voter, even in Radclfe, or Bury South or whatever, would be surprised at .probably the first of many, I would have thought, especially the newer MPs. I think a lot of the newer ones will do a similar thing. Meanwhile, Chris Holland said he rated Mr Wakeford as a local MP but had not voted for him. He said: Iaposve never voted Tory and I never would do. Iaposve messaged him a few times and he has got back to me. To me, heaposs not been doing too bad. Iaposd rather have a Labourthan a Tory. David Collins, who runs Marieaposs Coffee Shop, a stoneaposs throw from Mr Wakefordaposs constituency office, said: I probably wouldnapost vote for either of them anyway, Labour or Conservative. Theyaposre all as bad as each other. They all promise theyaposre going to do things and none of it ever materialises, does it  You wouldnapost think you were able to jump ship halfway through, would you   Tory voter Joan Humphreys said she feels like her tick at the ballot box has now been wasted. She said: I feel like going down there and saying, aposRight. I want to withdraw it.apos If he wants to become Labour, and he wants to support Labouraposs policies, we should have a by-election and see what the people say. If Boris had held his hands up at the beginning, people would have been far more forgiving about it, but heaposs not. But who are you going to have instead of Boris  I canapost see anybody . title: i survived 911 didnt discuss
story: I survived   - but didnt discuss it until my kids were taught it at schoolLisa Ridd was just  when two planes crashed into the Twin Towers on  September  - but for years, she didnt talk about it. But when her eldest child learned about the attacks at school, she faced up to her traumaLisa was just  when two planes crashed into the Twin TowersByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman who survived   has revealed she couldnapost look at photos of the attack for over a decade after it happened. Lisa Ridd was just  when two planes plunged into the World Trade Centre in New York on  September, . She was just yards from the Twin Towers when the planes hit - and recalls she originally thought the fuss around her was down to a parade nearby. Speaking to FEMAIL, Lisa said she only realised the true horror of what was happening when she saw a plane flying towards her. She recalled: Somebody said something about a bomb I thought Thataposs ridiculous, but quickly the older, more seasoned people on the trading floor told me to get off the phone - we are evacuating. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here After coming out onto the street, Lisa and hundreds of others started running as they saw the second plane heading for the North Tower. Somehow amid the chaos, she managed to find her sister who also worked in the World Trade Centre, and retreated to her apartment for safety. Although she survived the massacre, her best friend Lindsay, who worked on the th floor of the South Tower, did not. The pair had made friends four years earlier while studying at university in Massachusetts. According to Lisa, Lindsay was the biggest light in the room. But Lisa didnapost find out her best friendaposs fate until days after the attack, while she was recovering from the shock at her parentsapos house in Virginia.  As more stories emerged of survivors being pulled from the rubble, Lisa became convinced Lindsay would be one of them. For days she continued to call Lindsayaposs phone, willing her to pick up. But on  September when Lindsayaposs mum called to discuss her daughteraposs funeral arrangements, it sunk in for Lisa that her university pal was gone. Over the next few months, Lisa was offered counselling at work to process the trauma of being caught up in the terror attack, but she refused it. In fact, she recalls she avoided the topic entirely.  For the next decade, she couldnapost read about the attacks in the newspaper, look at photos of the Twin Towers or talk about what sheaposd lived through. While she suppressed her memories, Lisa met her now-husband and had three children, aged , six and two. But when her eldest child came home one day and asked her about  , Lisa realised she needed to make peace with her trauma. I was like aposOkay I guess I need to tell my kids my storyaposapos, she said. Since sitting her children down to tell them about her experience, Lisa has also gone back to the World Trade Centre and spent time at the memorial to the victims of  . She said: You have no idea when you see photos how powerful it is. There are holes that will never be filled up. All you can hear is the water rushing through, water is so therapeutic anyway and the way they designed it it feels like cleansing an endless cycle of energy. All of your senses are just alive and I really could not think of a more beautul way to memorialise that spot. Lisa has also appeared in a documentary about the attacks, Memory Box: Echoes of   in which she tells her story.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcShe believes speaking about it on TV has further helped her process her trauma. She said: Itaposs not a story that belongs to just me, itaposs a story that deserves to be passed down for future generations and I would say itaposs probably unlucky to be part of history in that way but thataposs the reality.Memory Box: Echoes of   is available on Sky and NOW TVRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON World Trade Center  attacks" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: britain should not involved tensions
story: Britain should not get involved in the tensions between Russia and UkrainePaul Routledge says we must not get dragged into the impending conflict between Russia and Ukraine. Armed Forces minister James Heappey warned tens of thousands could diewar breaks outVladimir Putin seems intent of rebuilding an influential Russian empire Image: SPUTNIK AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByPaul Routledge:,  Jan | comments All-out war between Russia and Ukraine appears imminent, and British brass hats can’t wait to join in.Armed Forces minister James Heappey talks blithely of the “grave possibility” of war with “tens of thousands dying.” Britain this week deployed an undisclosed number of Army personnel to the front line, a no manaposs land of freezing First World War-style trenches. They’re equipped with latest anti-tank weapons for use against the Red Army. They’re there to train Ukrainian soldiers, says the MoD, not to fight. But this is how wars begin. It’s called mission creep. The Americans were only in Vietnam to train local forces, until they weren’t. And look what happened.  If British soldiers come under direct fire, they must defend themselves. Then what  RAF sorties to take out attacking Russian forces  More, and bigger, military involvement  Tory MPs led by ex-officer Tobias Ellwood have formed a Charge of the Fight Brigade, egging on the military. How long before Boris Johnson begins to parade as the true successor to liberator Thatcher  But Donetsk isn’t British. This isn’t the Falklands. I’m no pacist –we’re invaded, stick a rle in my hands – and I hold no brief for dictator Vladimir Putin. His ambition to rebuild a Russian empire of influence from the ruins of the USSR is clear. But this is not our fight. They are not at the gates of Greenwich, and Nato is a reliable bulwark against any such danger. The Germans, who have much more to lose from a conflict close to their borders, promise “everything short of war”: punitive sanctions to hit the Russian economy hard. We should do the same. The coal mines of the Donbas are not worth the le of a single British soldier. title: coat banning school blames upsetting
story: Coat-banning school blames upsetting and abusive parents over strict new policyBishop Heber school in Malpas, Cheshire, believeschildren were allowed to wear their own coats it would "erode the great relationships" they have with their studentsParents are furious after a new strict branded unorm policy meant children were stopped from wearing their own coats outside Image: MEN MEDIABySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan | comments A school that stopped children wearing coats without its logo on have hit out at angry parents who called-out their strict policy.Pupils at Bishop Heber in Malpas, Cheshire, can only wear a costly branded jacket on school grounds, it has been decided.Mums and dads slammed the new unorm approach, which means their kids are prevented from wearing their own coats outside during breaks and to get to and from school, reports CheshireLive. Some even had their jackets confiscated as temperatures plunged during a chilly start to . Now Bishop Heber have hit out at the parents for abusive language while branding their fury upsetting. What do you think about this story  Let us know in the comments below  One mum said her asthmatic son was put into isolation for retrieving his seized coat because he was so cold. Photos taken by irate parents show staff milling around outside in warm overcoats while some children are just in thin jumpers with temperatures as low as C. Last week, the school said it believeskids were allowed to wear their own coats it would erode the great relationships we have with the students after fears they might end up wearing hoodies. After more backlash, they have now urged parents to raise concerns in a more formal manner.  A statement from the school read: Almost  years ago, the school made a commitment to an affordable unorm policy, and we believe the current unorm is one of the cheapest to buy in the region and complies with the affordable school unorm legislation being introduced this year. The coat was chosen and designed by students in  and costs £. The school is confident that students are not sitting in classrooms that are unusually cold for the time of year and students should not need to wear coats to keep warm. Additionally, all students have access to an indoor space and or classroom during any breaks.  We hope that parents and the wider community appreciate that governors and school leaders are trying to do their best in what has been an exceptionally dficult period for us all. Governors hope that parents will use the school complaints policythey have a concern. Such complaints can be dealt with formally and carefully and without some of the upsetting, abusive and inflammatory language that has been directed at staff and governors. Parents complained about the cost and quality of the branded windcheater which costs £. One angry mum fumed: “They confiscated his my sonaposs coat yesterday - outside - which I thought was absolutely ludicrous. He has asthma, which he is on constant medication for, so getting cold does him no good whatsoever. Because he went and got his coat back because he was cold, he has been put into isolation, that was his punishment. “Why would you take a coat off a child when you know they’ve got asthma  She added: “Kids should not be worried about getting into trouble for keeping warm. news uk-news covid-cases-among-children-rise-"Covid: Cases in UK rise by ,ByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsCovid cases in school-age children are on the rise once again according to new data from the ZOE Covid study.This comes as NHS staff absences linked to Covid- are now falling with a drop of a quarter in the last week.The ZOE study, using a popular monitoring app developed by King’s College London, estimated that one in  Brits had symptomatic Covid three days ago. It estimated such cases among under-s have increased from around , new daily cases at the start of December up to almost ,. NHS England announced staff Covid absences “are going in the right direction” but warned “staff will have many tough months ahead”.  Some , NHS staff at hospital trusts in England were absent for Covid- reasons on January , down % on the previous week. However this is still more than double that seen at the start of December.This includes staff ill with coronavirus or having to self-isolate due to close contacts.In the latest release the Zoe study put the UKaposs R value at .. Lead scientist Prof Tim Spector said: “In just two weeks the number of new cases per day has fallen around % from its peak of over , to under ,. “New cold-like symptoms are now again slightly more likely to just be a cold and not Covid. “While it is easy to think the worst is over, our health service is still not ing properly.  “The ZOE data is already showing an uptick in symptomatic cases in children due to the back to school effect.” There were , NHS staff at hospital trusts in England who were absent for all sickness reasons on January , down % on the previous week. NHS England medical director Prof Stephen Powis said: “Even though the numbers are going in the right direction, NHS staff will have many tough months ahead as they continue to deliver patient care while managing competing demands.  “While staff absences remain high and continue to increase in some parts of the country it is good to see they have been reducing week on week. “The number of people in hospital for both Covid and non-covid care remains high, and arrivals at AE via ambulance increased by more than ,. news uk-news covid-pcr-tests-could-replaced-"Covid-: Dr Hilary says vaccine mandate should be scrappedBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Scientists believe they have developed an almost-instant Covid diagnosis test that will use X-rays instead of PCR tests with an accuracy of %. The Articial Intelligence programme would offer results within minutes and would be a big boost to healthcare staff, it has been claimed. Experts at the University of the West of Scotland say the speed of results would aid the frontline battle against the deadly bug.A PCR test typically takes around two hours to inform of a positive or negative result. But the Articial Intelligence programme detects the virus much faster and the idea would boost hospital care around the world.  An AI process uses an algorithm to analyse visual imagery and make a quick diagnosis. Professor Naeem Ramzan led the three-person team behind the project, which also involved Gabriel Okolo and Dr Stamos Katsigiannis.In his latest update, he wrote: There has long been a need for a quick and reliable tool that can detect Covid-, and this has become even more true with the upswing of the Omicron iant.Several countries are unable to carry out large numbers of covid tests because of limited diagnosis tools, but this technique utilises easily accessible technology to quickly detect the virus.  Covid- symptoms are not visible in x-rays during the early stages of infection, so it is important to note that the technology cannot fully replace PCR tests. However, it can still play an important role in curtailing the viruses spread especially when PCR tests are not readily available. It could prove to be crucial, and potentially le-saving, when diagnosing severe cases of the virus, helping determine what treatment may be required.  Professor Milan Radosavljevic, Vice-Principal of Research, Innovation and Engagement at UWS, hailed the signicance of the development. This is potentially game-changing research, he said. Itaposs another example of the purposeful, impactful work that has gone on at UWS throughout the pandemic, making a genuine dference in the fight against Covid-. I am incredibly proud of the drive and innovation demonstrated by our internationally renowned academics, as they strive to find solutions to urgent global problems. title: dozens pets left limp lifeless
story: Dozens of dogs are left limp, leless and vomiting as mystery illness spreadsHundred of dogs have experienced similar symptoms prompting vet warnings to avoid coastal walks. where cases have been reported at beaches in YorkshireThe six-month-old lurcher became extremely poorly. Image: MEN MEDIAByGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsDozens of pets have been left aposlimp, leless and vomitingapos as a mystery dog illness spreads. Nicola Jane took her lurcher along a canal towpath and he became ill only hours later..The six-month old dog contracted an infection which almost killed him for five days after the walk.A friendaposs dog which she was also exercising also became ill but managed to recover after they were exercised at Hunslet Canal., Yorkshire.The animals both had symptoms within four hours of the walk and aposseemed off.Hundred of dogs have experienced similar symptoms prompting vet warnings to avoid coastal walks. Cases have been reported at Hayling Island beach and Langstone Harbour in Hampshire, Fraisthorpe Beach in East Riding, Bridlington and Redcar beach.  Nicola, of Leeds, West Yorkshire said aposI woke up around am on night four, and just thought I was losing him. I thought he was dead, he was shaking and being sick, he was limp in my arms I thought he wasnapost coming back from this. At that point in the night I took him to the emergency vet, I was really shocked with the numbers that were there. I was terried.apos The Daily Mail reports that blood tests were carried out and the vet kept the pet overnight and monitored IV fluids.Nicola added: He is a mess, he is like a skeleton he is that skinny. He lost that much weight. There was nothing on him, no le, he was limp, I thought he was gone, I thought I was losing him. Vets told her a virus which was originally from beaches was spreading.  The animal doctors warned her to avoid the popular dog walking areas at the coast because it is spreading from dog to dog very quickly.Earlier this month The Mirror told about a more than a hundred dog illnesses which had struck down animals. Veterinary nurse Brogan Proud, who runs Yorkshire Coast Pet Care posted a message on Facebook where she said that she had been inundated with ill dogs that have been vomiting and suffering from diarrhoea.She said that local authorities were investigating what is behind the illness and that worryingly a lot more dogs have been affected than she previously thought as more people have contacted her. As itaposs gone so public, it just seems to be much higher numbers than I thought. I know the local authorities have been testing, they canapost find anything as of yetBefore that incident The Mirror reported animals had been affected in Yorkshire.Vet practices in the region then shared warnings on Facebook, urging owners to avoid beaches in Scarborough and Saltburn.The bug was then thought to be moving inland to towns and cities, including Hebden Bridge, York, and Sheffield, reported similar symptoms. One person posted on a group in Hebden Bridge saying: The dog sickness bug is spreading here like wildfire. My dog came down it on Thursday and I had only taken her to school and back! Relatives of Nicola, , have also had their dogs admitted to the vets, some for three days. Dog owners told how his Great Dane died after contracting lung infection from swimming in apospollutedapos sea water. David Arthuraposs -month-old dog Odin swam at Hayling Island in Portsmouth, Hampshire, but had to be put to down because of the infection He had already spent £, on treating Odin but the animalaposs lungs were damaged from pneumonia, with the sea thought to be the likely cause of infection. A £, vet bill faced the owner of another dog after her Staffordshire bull terrier swam in polluted sea water. Nalu was infected after swimming at Langstone which terried her owner Louisa Moss. The pooch became so ill she had to be put on a ventilator and was struggling to breathe and her owners were told she might die. title: great great gran 100 meets
story: Great-great-gran, , meets first girl born in her family for  yearsGwen Smith, who will turn  next month, has met little Maeva for the first time. The girl is the first female born to the Smiths since Gwens daughter Sandra was born in Gwen Smith met her great-great-granddaughter MaevaByAdam AspinallNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A -year-old pensioner has welcomed her great-great-granddaughter into the world - the first girl born into the family for  years.Gwen Smith met little Maeva for the first time - the first female born to the Smiths since her daughter Sandra was born in . Five generations of the family were able to get together at the Dene Holm Residential Care Home in Northfleet, Kent, as the oldest and youngest members could be united for the first time. Gwen, who will turn  next month, already has five grandsons, eight great-grandsons and six step great-grandsons and she was extremely proud to meet the newest addition to the family. Unfortunately, her cataracts mean she can no longer see very well but she was still tremendously happy to meet Maeva. Gwen’s family said: “It was a very special occasion to get all five generations together, particularly during the pandemic. Strict protocols are still in place but the home’s manager, Chris, permitted the visit for which we are all extremely grateful.”  Gwen was born in Essex on th February , she moved to Gravesend as a youngster and went to school in Northfleet. A keen dancer in her youth, she performed at many local events while working her father’s shop. Gwen met her husband, Ron, an apprentice electrician at Blue Circle Cement Works, when she was . They married in  but with Ron sent to serve overseas with the Royal Engineers, they didn’t meet again for another five years. When they were finally reunited, the pair enjoyed many years of travelling whilst bringing up their two daughters, Gloria and Sandra. A care home spokesman said: It can be dficult to get several generations of family together at the best of times but with an ongoing pandemic, it’s even trickier. But thanks to the staff at the Dene Holm Road care home, Gwen’s family were able to come and visit her together, to introduce her to baby Maeva. It was a very rare occasion and indeed, incredibly special for the whole family, particularly as little Maeva is the first girl to be born to the family since Gwen’s daughter, Sandra,  years ago. title: happy cheeky funny boy 13
story: Happy, cheeky, funny boy, , dies after being hit by train at railway stationDevin Gordon, , was reportedly hit by a train near Bathgate railway station in West Lothian, Scotland, on Wednesday, according to British Transport PoliceDevin Gordon was reportedly hit by a train Image: Bathgate Juniors Football ClubByDan BarkerRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The family of a teenager who died after reportedly being hit by a train have said their lives will never be the same without our precious boy. Devin Gordon, , died near Bathgate railway station in West Lothian, Scotland, on Wednesday afternoon, British Transport Policesaid.In a tribute to the keen footballer, his family said he will live in our hearts forever. In their statement, issued by the police, they continued: Our lives have changed forever and will never be the same without our precious boy. We will miss him every day for the rest of our lives. Thank-you to everyone thataposs paid tribute to Devin and those that have sent us condolence messages during this extremely dficult time.Have you been affected by this incident  Let us know at webnews@mirrorHearts fan Devin was a member of Bathgate Juniors Football Club, which described him as a great team player and friend who will be greatly missed by his football family. It said: Devin was a light in the team which will never go out. His personality like a magnet drawing people to him. Happy, cheeky but funny with it and always respectful. On the field he showed his passion and skill. He made the team a better place to be. He was a great team player and friend who will be greatly missed by his football family. Our thoughts are now with Devinaposs family, friends and his team who will hold him in their hearts foreverthe only number .  Emergency services had attended the scene, but could not save the youngster. Police said his death is not been treated as suspicious and a report will be sent to the procurator fiscal. Emergency services raced to the scene at around .pm yesterday but sadly the teen could not be saved and was pronounced dead. A BTP statement said: British Transport Police were called to Bathgate station at .pm todayfollowing reports of a casualty on the tracks. Paramedics also attended, and sadly a person was pronounced dead at the scene. The incident is not being treated as suspicious and a file will be prepared for the procurator fiscal. Devinaposs friends are hoping to get a -minute applause around Heartsapos Tynecastle Park when the side face Celtic next Wednesday. news uk-news how-soon-can-you-covid-"Sajid Javid on self-isolation rules eventually coming to an endByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments After a recent spike in cases from the Omicron iant, Covid seems to finally be falling in the UK, where Plan B restrictions are in the process of being scrapped. Despite this, the virus continues to be rampant and risk of infections still remains high. When someone catches Covid, their immune system usually generates a response that helps their body fight off the virus and protects them from future infections. However, some people end up getting re-infected as their immunity begins to wane.So,youaposve recently caught Covid and youaposre wondering how long you might remain immune to it before the risk of catching it again - hereaposs everything you need to know. How soon can I catch Covid again   After someone catches Covid, their bodies builds antibodies that help fight against the virus. However, itaposs not known how long immunity from infection lasts, and it can also y from person to person.A recent Public Health Englandstudy found that more people who have had coronavirus are protected from catching it again for at least five months.However, a government website states that a new infection could occur within  days - or three months - of being infected once. This would be mean that people who have the virus in October could be vulnerable to catching it again this month. Sometimes, the immune response doesnapost last as long as five or three months and people end up getting re-infected twice in one month. The Omicron iant, which has more mutations than previous iants, is thought to be more likely to cause reinfection than iants like Delta. However, UK studies are yet to look into Omicron re-infection rates in more detail. Itaposs worth noting that residual signs of Covid infection can show up on a PCR test for up to three months, evena person is not displaying any symptoms. Do I need to self-isolateIaposve already had Covid before   Yes,you have symptoms of Covid or have tested positive for the virus, you will need to self-isolate, evenyou have already contracted the virus in the past few months. You will also need to self-isolateyouaposve not been vaccinated and live with someone who has tested positive. This applies evenyou have had recently been infected, as this would be a new infection and you are considered contagious again. Guidelines from Gov.uk state: If an inidual is re-tested  days or more after their initial illness onset or prior test date, and is found to be PCR positive, this should be considered as a possible new infection. news uk-news inside-derelict-housing-estate-became-"Liverpool housing estate where residents fear for their safetyByCharlotte Hadfield:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsPeople living in a derelict housing estate which has become the focus of a viral TikTok video have spoken about the realities of le in its streets. The footage of Primrose Court in Huyton, Merseyside has racked up more than five million views.A voiceover on the video, which was created by a TikTok user scrolling on Google Street View, says: Look at the f****** state of this street in Liverpool.It shows derelict homes with their windows boarded back in September , while music from the horror film Dead Silence plays over the top of it.Residents living in the area told the Liverpool Echo they feared for their safety due to gangs torching houses and setting fires in the street.The issue of crime coupled with fly-tippers targeting the area has caused many people to move out of the area.  One man, who did not want to be named for safety reasons, told the ECHO: I feel unsafe. Thereaposs a gang - they donapost want to see this area getting better. All the time people are bringing their rubbish and they make fires. I canapost describe it to be honest with you, it looks like Beirut. Iaposm looking for a safe le, Iaposm not looking for trouble. Every day Iaposm going to work, I pay my bills. I remember one man moved in and he left after a couple of months because he wasnapost safe here. Theyaposre nice houses but for some reason, these people donapost want to see this area getting better. The problems with Primrose Court appear to have started when the development was first built by two private companies who went bust before work on site was completed. This means key elements such as street lighting and ‘proper kerbs’ have not been installed on the road. And because the road is unadopted, the duty to maintain it belongs to the owners of the properties.  In a previous interview with the ECHO, one woman who did not want to be named said she lived in a house on Primrose Court for seven years until she couldnapost take anymore. She said: It was nice when I first moved in. They were lovely houses. It went really bad around June . One family moved in and the next minute they all turned up. That was when it all went downhill. After the families moved out of the houses, which are privately owned, the woman said kids living in the area continued to vandalise them by smashing up windows. Speaking to the ECHO earlier this month, the owner of A Properties, Colin Bell, said of the  houses he manages across the region the  properties he owns on Primrose Court create % of our problems.  On average, Colin said he spends around one and a half to two days a week on the estate attending to issues and clearing up rubbish that has been left there. Colin said: All around Primrose Court there are nice properties going up and being sold immediately. The area is ripe for investment but weaposre stuck with Primrose Court simply because of the council really, I donapost know how many times Iaposve rung up asking whataposs happening or sent emails. They come back with the same thing apostheyaposre hoping to get funding.apos Of the  properties on Primrose Court, Colin said nine of the houses, which are owned by dferent landlords, are currently empty - and four of them are believed to have been derelict for over  years.Colin claims that in October , Knowsley Council promised street lighting would be installed and work on the road would be completed on the grounds that each property owner would pay towards the work. He said: Itaposs a crazy situation. Over two years ago now we agreed for the council to do the work and we would repay the council. For any of the houses that we didnapost repay, the council would repossess the houses and they would have charge of them. We were told the work would be completed in nine months - this was pre-covid. Up to now, weaposre still no further on. However, Knowsley Council has disputed these claims and said the properties on Primrose Court are all privately owned and the council never agreed to repossess them. A Knowsley Council spokesperson said: “Knowsley Council did not build the properties at Primrose Court and has never owned them. It is therefore not the case that we are able to aposrepossessapos them and we have never agreed to do so. “In fact, many of the issues at Primrose Court arise because the development was built by two separate privately-owned companies – both of which went into liquidation without completing the work on-site and without meeting the planning conditions for the developments.  This meant that the usual processes for adopting the highway, installing street lighting etc could not be followed and the same problem prevents the installation of other measures such as CCTV. The current property owners expect the Council to use a considerable amount of public money to complete a privately owned development. “The Council has been in regular dialogue with the homeowners and landlords of properties in Primrose Court since the initial issues arose in the area. The council continued: A number of Council services, including Housing, Highways, Environmental Health, and Crime  Communities, have worked with homeowners and landlords to identy solutions to the issues on site, try to identy sources of funding, and agree a collaborative approach to tackling the issues that are evident. “For example, the Council met with some of the owners to discuss co-funding highways and infrastructure improvements to bring the road up to adoptable standards. At that meeting, the owners who attended agreed - in principle - to co-fund this work. Unfortunately some of the other owners who did not attend refused to agree to contribute their shares, which would be required to progress the adoption of the road under a Private Streetworks Agreement. The Council has established how much the work would cost should an agreement ever be reached, but these costs are only going to continue to increase as time passes due to the poor original construction of the road by the developers. “Unfortunately, the Council is not in a position itself to fund all of the work which is required on site. Indeed, this would not be appropriate given that the Council does not own any housing and is not able to re-possess privately-owned properties. “Despite this challenge, the Council continues to look at solutions to tackle the issues being experienced and we are bidding for additional funding to carry out work in the area. Only last year, we pledged an extra £ million of funds specically to tackle crime and anti-social behaviour across the Borough – which is a key issue here. “The standards at Primrose Court are not acceptable and we remain committed to working with the owners on collaborative solutions to resolve the issues for all concerned.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON GoogleKing of the KippaxCCTVViralCCTV footageCrimeGoogle Street View" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news kate-middleton-jokes-dog-upset-"Kate Middleton and Prince William cuddle pup on visit to LancashireByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge couldnapost hide her delight after she got to cuddle up to a cute puppy on a visit to a hospital today - and joked her own dog would be upset. Kate and husband Prince William were at Clitheroe Community Hospital in Lancashire this afternoon meeting staff to learn what it has been like for them during the coronavirus pandemic.For the visit, Kate wore a recycled £ Massimo Dutti that sheaposs been spotted wearing at two other engagements. She teamed the coat with a gorgeous camel polo neck jumper and matching skirt and completed the look with tan boots. During the visit to the hospital, Kate and William got to meet  week-old cockapoo Alfie.The pup, who licked Williamaposs cheek, will be trained to support patients and colleagues at the East Lancashire HospitalsNHS Trust alongside therapy dog Jasper.Kate described the pup as so sweet but, after enjoying a cuddle, added: Our dog is going to be very upset.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. The couple also met GPs, nurses, and patients at the hospital. William told staff: Weaposre so grateful for all your hard work. Iaposm not sure there are enough words to say how grateful everyone is for what you have done. He said he had a particular affinity with staff because of his time as an air ambulance pilot. Lisa Kay, intensive home support service clinical lead, said: That was great to hear because itaposs not every day you get a royal visit to say thank you.  It has been a huge morale boost. Patient Bill Taylor, , was asked by the royals about the care he had received at the hospital and joked: Theyaposre trying their best but thereaposs some awkward b*****s. The retired policeman praised the hospital food, telling the couple he had a grand meat and potato pie for his lunch. He said: We all enjoy ourselves up here. But weaposd like you to come up more often.  He pointed out Pendle Hill, seen from the window of his ward, and told them: The kids would enjoy it.The Duke and Duchess, who are joint royal patrons of NHS Charities Together, heard how support from hospital charity ELHTMe had helped staff at the trust, which is in one of the areas of the country worst affected by Covid-.A grant of more than £, from NHS Charities Together, following the public response to its Covid- Urgent Appeal, allowed the charity to fund equipment and infrastructure for the staff wellbeing team, as well as the new therapy dog. Director of operations Catriona Logan said the duchess was really interested to know how the pandemic had been for staff. She said: We talked about how dficult it was for patients and families being separated by visiting restrictions. She was really engaging. Professor Eileen Fairhurst, trust chairwoman, added: It was really uplting for our staff a real morale boost that their work has been recognised by this high profile visit, and itaposs testament to the hard work and commitment of all our colleagues in the trust in the real challenges and dficulties we have faced since the pandemic. We have been hardest hit in this part of the country and it has really not gone away. news uk-news meghan-markle-prince-harry-might-"Prince Harry files claim over police protection for familyByLorraine KingNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Prince Harry and Meghan Markle could miss Prince Philip’s upcoming memorialtheir security fight is not resolved.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are expected to attend the service in spring this year and finally introduce seven-month old Lilibet to the Queen and other members of the royal family.But the plans are on hold due to Harryaposs legal dispute with the UK Government over a decision not to let him pay for police protection for his family when he is visiting.A legal representative of the prince said he wants to bring Lilibet and two-year-old son Archie to visit from the US but they are “unable toto his home” because it is too dangerous. Last July, Harry was reportedly chased by a pack of photographers after he attended a charity event with sick children at Kew Gardens, west London.Whose side are you on  Have your say in the comment section The -year-old had flown back briefly from LA for the July  unveiling of the Diana, Princess of Wales memorial statue. The Sussexes have their own security in the US, but sources said the privately paid-for team have no authority whatsoever in the UK.And one royal source has now told Page Six : “If Harry goes, he will want to have security for him and his family. If and when he decides to go back to the UK, he needs security.” The couple have not announced any official travel plans for  as yet but it has been widely believed they would attend the service in memory of the Duke of Edinburgh who died last April at the age of . This would be the first time Lilbet would meet her paternal side of her family as Meghan has not ed to the UK since the couple officially quit royal le in March  and lost their taxpayer-funded police protection. The Mirror has contacted the Sussexes for a comment.  On Saturday, Harryaposs legal representatives said that he has filed a claim for judicial review because he wants to fund the security himself, rather than ask taxpayers to foot the bill. He has argued that his private protection team in the US does not have the necessary jurisdiction abroad, or access to UK intelligence that is needed to keep his family safe.In a statement to PA news agency, the legal representative for the Duke said: “The UK will always be Prince Harry ’s home and a country he wants his we and children to be safe in. “With the lack of police protection, comes too great a personal risk. “The Duke and Duchess of Sussex personally fund a private security team for their family, yet that security cannot replicate the necessary police protection needed whilst in the UK. “In the absence of such protection, Prince Harry and his family are unable toto his home.” The legal representative added: “Prince Harry inherited a security risk at birth, for le. He remains sixth in line to the throne, served two tours of combat duty in Afghanistan, and in recent years his family has been subjected to well-documented neo-Nazi and extremist threats.  “While his role within the Institution has changed, his profile as a member of the Royal Family has not. Nor has the threat to him and his family.” The bid for a judicial review was filed in September. Dai Davies, former head of Scotland Yard’s royal protection unit, told the Mirror: If ever there was a proper credible threat to Prince Harry or his family then the Met would take the appropriate action. “If he or his family were toto Britain in an official capacity or to support the Queen during the Platinum Jubilee events I’m sure he would be afforded the necessary protection. “I would argue robustly against his case that he is not safe in the UK. If ever the British intelligence services did discover a threat to him and his family they are hardly going to sit on it. It appears that Harry is creating scenarios that do not exist.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Meghan MarklePrince HarryPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news omicron-symptoms-parents-able-spot-"Omicron: The first eight symptoms to look out forByHarry ThompsonTrends WriterEmma Gill:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments As the world continues to get to grips with Omicron and understand what its symptoms are, people have been talking and sharing brilliantly about their experiences with the virus.The exchange of information has helped put together an image of what the symptoms of the virus are while proper research from scientists has been ongoing.This also extends to concerned parents looking to share what they have found in their children and to help others spot the signs of Omicron early. The NHS hasnapost changed its official information yet about what the symptoms of the latest strain are, and so parents are continuing to get information out about the dferences between it and previous iants such as Delta, the Manchester Evening News reports. Using their Manchester Family Facebook page, the MEN has been asking parents to share how the virus has been affecting their youngsters.At the time of writing, the official NHS advice still reports a new and persistent cough, a loss of taste or smell and a fever as the main symptoms - but read on for how parents say the virus is dfering for their kids. What Omicron symptoms have parents seen in their kids   The first thing to note is how dferent the responses were between familiesapos experiences - while some kids had little to no symptoms, others were left quite unwell by the virus. The number of hospitalisations among infants has risen during the Omicron wave, although experts are still saying that the majority of cases are very mild and that people shouldnapost panic. Data published by the Scientic Advisory Group, or SAGE, on January  said that in previous waves approximately % of children hospitalised with Covid were under the age of one. Between mid-December  and January, this number rose to %. Despite this, they say severity is still low, with SAGE saying: For the small number of children who do attend hospital, theof stay is typically short and where they stay overnight it is often to allow for screening for other infections.The most common symptoms reported on the Facebook page were a cold, a temperature and a headache. More than  parents said their kids had suffered from a headache,  said there had been fever or temperature and  reported cold-like symptoms or a runny nose. Thirty-three parents also got in touch saying there had been tiredness or that their child hadnapost had any energy and was generally sleepy.A cough was reported in over two dozen cases, and while it was mild for some, others had a rougher time of it with a similar number identying a sore throat.Sickness and stomach ache also cropped up among the responses, as did a loss of appetite and taste . Achy backs and legs, as well as general muscle aches, were also flagged. Some kids also had diarrhoea or an upset stomach, pale skin, bloodshot eyes or sneezing. news uk-news prince-andrew-demanded-room-temperature-"Prince Andrew: Former royal bodyguard discusses teddiesBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Prince Andrew demanded his water be strictly served at room temperature and that his valet haul around a six-foot ironing board on foreign trips, it has been claimed. Sources say the Duke was known for being rude and having childish obsessions - as he was ridiculed while on the road fulfilling royal duties, reports claim.It comes after reports the embattled Duke of York would allegedly scream and shoutBuckingham Palace servants failed to follow his exact plan for the arrangement of his teddy bears. Now more supposed demanding behaviour has come to light during his term as the UKaposs special representative for trade and investment. It includes suggestions he was privately mocked in the Gulf during his time as a special envoy.  A diplomat says the Prince became known as HBH - His Buffoon Highness. The former deputy head of mission in Bahrain, Simon Wilson, says the royalaposs travelling entourage left people speechless. He told The Times Andrew flew out a team which included his equerries and private secretaries. His valet would be equipped with a huge ironing board to ensure his clothes were perfectly pressed, it was claimed.  The diplomat, who had previously hosted the Duke, added that Andrew was rude and boorish and wasnapost well-liked. Mr Wilson explained he was known as a buffoon because of his childish obsession with doing the exact opposite of what had been agreed. He immediately warned that Andrewaposs private le would “willy-nilly, intrude into his public role” – and that he could be “going off with Ghislaine Maxwell to a nightclub” during his private time, it was claimed.Andrew has effectively been banished from the royal family less than  hours after learning a civil sex case against him in New York will go ahead.  The latest awkward anecdotes come after Tuesdayaposs claims that Andrew sketched out a plan for how his five teddies and cuddly toys should be positioned on his bed every night. Ex protection officer Paul Page tells ITV ’s Ghislaine, Prince Andrew and the Paedophile that would “scream and shout”his servants failed to place them exactly how he wanted. He supplied a handwritten guide is said to have included two hippos, a black panther and bears, as well as three cushions called aposDaddyapos, aposDucksapos and aposPrinceapos. It showed exactly where to place blankets, as well as five toys and a fur, which had ribbons that had to hang off the side of the bed, it is said. Ghislaine, Prince Andrew and the Paedophile host Ranvir Singh unravels the story of how Maxwell sank into shame and disgrace through her friendship with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. And will also explore how Andrew became embroiled in the scandal as he faces his own possible civil court case brought by Virginia Giuffre. Andrew has strenuously denied the allegations made by Ms Giuffre against him. news uk-news queen-holding-up-hands-despair-"Ranvir Singh attempts to call Prince Andrews mobileByAnna MathesonCelebrity and Entertainment WriterRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan  The Queen will be in despair over the actions of certain members of the royal family in recent weeks, an expert claims. Royal correspondent Jennie Bond has spoken of the Queenaposs apparent upset after a New York judge gave the green light for a civil sex abuse trial against her second son, Prince Andrew.Pending the trial, the Queen stripped him of all royal and military titles, leaving him in tears. The Duke of York has absolutely and categorically denied all allegations. Following his relegation, the Governmentaposs Armed Forces Minister James Heappey said Andrewaposs behaviour would have caused enormous challenges for the royal family. Meanwhile, Prince Harry threatened the Home Office with a judicial review should they refuse to provide him a security detail while visiting the UK. Ex-BBC royal correspondent Ms Bond believes the Queen will be feeling the strain and in despair over recent events involving more junior members of the Firm. Speaking to OK!, Ms Bond explained: I think The Queen will be holding her hands up in despair with her children and some of her grandchildren.She added there should be equity between Harry, who was stripped of titles when he renounced royal duties in , and Prince Andrew, who should have been demoted some time ago. She said: Everybody feels for the Queen now with the Andrew debacle, but I think there has to be some equity between Harry and Andrew now. There was the argument and it probably wasnapost correct, butHarry has been stripped of his titles then Andrew should have been some time ago.. Harry also made headlines this week as itaposs been reported that he could be planning to take legal action against the British governmenthe is denied police protection when he visits the UK.The Duke of Sussex issued a pre-protocol letter to the Home Office suggesting his lawyers will seek judicial reviewcontinued police security isn’t provided by the UK when he and his family are in the country. Harryaposs lawyers made it clear he is happy to pay for the added protection It comes after Harry made a series of visits to the UK over the past year, but claims his security situation lacked continuity ,changing from one visit to the next. While in the UK to attend his granddadaposs funeral in April, bodyguards were protecting him and his family. However, when he ed later that same year in July to witness the unveiling of a statue of his late mum, Princess Diana, he was without security. A safety concern was raised after a group of photographers chased his car as he left the charity event. A legal representative for Prince Harry said the legal claim was filed in September to challenge the decision-making behind the security procedures, in the hopes that this could be re-evaluated for the obvious and necessary protection required. According to Ms Bond, Prince Andrewaposs security should be revised too. She said: If Harry is not going to be allowed to have security over here unless heaposs staying in a royal residence then perhaps Andrewaposs security should be looked at too. On the other hand, the expert says Harry should look at the le he has chosen after moving to the US. She explains: There has to be some kind of equity between the two of them but Harry needs to look at himself, heaposs chosen this way of le, he wants to be regarded as a royal citizen, and he canapost pick and choose like this. Ms Bond added that Prince Harry canapost have it both ways. She explained: He canapost be treated as a royal with all of the trimmings while heaposs over here and then swan off back to the states and say that youaposre not. news uk-news queen-never-meet-lilibet-amid-"Prince Harry files claim over police protection for familyByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | comments Thereaposs a big possibility the Queen may never get to meet her great-granddaughter Lilibet, according to a royal expert.Prince Harry and Meghan Markleaposs seven-month-old daughter was born in Calornia in June and her parents have yet to bring her to the UK.Since moving to the US, Meghan and two-year-old Archie have not ed at all, and Harry has only been back twice. And at the weekend, Harry revealed the reason why heaposs yet to bring his family to his homeland. He claims his private security arrangements are not enough to ensure his family’s safety and privacy here. He and Meghan are no longer entitled to police protection.  Harry now wants to pay for specialist police protection, but the Home Office has ruled this out – and he has applied for a judicial review against the decision. If the row canapost be solved, Harry might choose not to bring his young children to the UK.And with the Queen no longer flying long-haul, royal expert Phil Dampier told The Sun itaposs a big possibility she is never going to meet her granddaughter Lilibet and has only ever met Archie once or twice.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. He also added: Getting his protection reinstated would set a precedent and so it gives them the perfect opportunity to say we can’t come to Platinum Jubilee celebrations. Harry might come over but it gives Meghan a good excuse not to come and also not to bring the children. Meanwhile, another royal expert previously claimed the Queen finds it dficult that she has been unable to see Harry and Meghan’s children.Speaking in the Channel  documentary : The Queen’s Terrible Year, royal expert Camilla Tominey says it has been hard for the Queen to be so far away from her two great-grandchildren. She said: Iaposm sure the Queen was absolutely delighted to hear the news that the Sussexes were expecting a second child. She continued: But it is dficult for the Queen. She has not been able to see Archie. I think the last time she was able to see Archie in the flesh was November . The only way the Queen will be able to see these children isthey come over to the UK. Maybe she will see them next year when she marks her Platinum Jubilee. We have to wait and see. news uk-news queens-very-specic-morning-bath-"The Queen’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations programme in fullByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsFor most people, their everyday lives mean they often roll out of bed and only have time for a quick shower before itaposs time for work.But the Queen does not have an everyday le like the rest of us - and it seems her morning routine is quite dferent to the normal.And this means rather than jumping in the shower, she prefers to have a morning bath to set her up for the day ahead.According to royal author Brian Hoey, after Her Majesty wakes and has her first cup of tea of the day, the next thing she does is have her bath. But rather than run it herself, a maid does it for her to make sure it is to her exact preference.The author explained in the Daily Mail : While Her Majesty is enjoying her first cup of tea, her maid will go into the adjoining bathroom to draw the bath, which has to be exactly the right temperature: tested with a wooden-cased thermometer, and no more than seven inches of water. While sheaposs enjoying her soak, her dresser Angela Kelly is then said to prepare the Queenaposs outfit and once sheaposs finished her bath Her Majesty then gets dressed and fixes her hair ready for breakfast at .am.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. But why is it the Queen would prefer a time-consuming bath to a quick shower  Well author Craig Brown, who wrote Ma’am Darling:  Glimpses of Princess Margaret, once offered an answer. He once told W Magazine: She [Margaret] always took a bath because she and other royals believe ‘showers are for people who are rushing out the door to get to work’.”However, itaposs not just the Queen who has specic demands when it comes to baths.  Former butler Paul Burrell, who worked closely with Princess Diana and her family in the s revealed Prince Charlesapos routine on the Amazon Primeaposs documentary Serving the Royals: Inside the Firm.He told the documentary: The water temperature has to be just tepid, and only half full.” The ex-butler also added that the bath plug must face a specic direction, his bath towel must be arranged to his taste and his underwear can’t be a crease out of place. news uk-news uk-milk-formula-shortage-left-"New mum struggles to find premature baby formulaByChristian BrayfordAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA new mum says she is struggling to feed her two-month-old daughter because of a national shortage of a special formula for premature babies. Shannon Gadd, , gave birth to Fiadh Rose Hughes in November at Diana, Princess of Wales Hospital in Grimsby.She was born weighing two pounds and  ounces and requires Cow  Gateaposs Nutriprem  formula - which helps preterm and low birth-weight babies gain weight after leaving the hospital, GrimsbyLive reports. The formula is full of key vitamins and minerals to support their nutritional needs before they can start on a normal infant diet. Shannon has been unable to buy the formula because of a national shortage, which caused little Fiadh to become sick and dehydrated. Have you struggled to find formula  Email us about your story, webnews@mirror  She said: Not being on the formula is taking its toll on Fiadhaposs health. Sheaposs started to have more reflux and she also started having a tar-like bowel motion. Iaposm so worried for Fiadh because the doctor has confirmed that it’s to do with the many diet changes. The question I ask now is, how am I going to feed my baby   We’ve had to go out and get normal milk which we know makes her sick and it’s not enriched enough so sheaposs going to lose weight. I don’t know what we are supposed to do. Shannon says her formula first ran out on December  and sheaposs been struggling to find any since. The new mum said: I was told Fiadh had stopped growing two weeks prior to her birth because of a growth issue so a doctoraposs performed a Caesarean.  She was taken into the NICU for five weeks where I used breast milk in a bottle for eight weeks to give her the best fighting chance. But her weight dropped and she needed extra calories because my milk wasn’t enough for her growing appetite. I took the very hard decision to try and transition her into the formula with Cow and Gate Nutriprem  recommended. She loved it but we last ran out on December  and havenapost been able to order any since. Shannon has resorted to using a dferent formula, which she says has had a detrimental impact on Fiadhaposs development. She said: We were doing well until Fiadh took a turn for the worst on December  when she began to be sick from the new formula.  She was taking a little amount of milk and then bringing it back up so she was really hungry and upset. I was getting worried about her so I rang  and they told me to be seen by someone immediately. A doctor admitted us straight away and said Fiadh was going to need to be treated for dehydration. Shannon said: She only weighs five pounds and six ounces to this day and is below her centile - a growth chart indicating where a guideline baby should be at their age. Iaposve been told how important the Cow  Gate formula is but I canapost buy it anywhere. Iaposve been to chemists and pharmacies in Hull, Scunthorpe, Immingham and Grimsby to be told itaposs out of stock. Iaposve tried contacting Cow  Gate to find thereaposs a national shortage of this product. It feels like I’ve been passed from pillar to post without any joy. How can it be out of stock when it’s made only for premature and underweight babies  for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.A representative from Danone said: We were sorry to hear about Shannon’s story. We are experiencing some short-term, isolated incidents of low availability on our Cow  Gate Nutriprem  g powder formula product. We do appreciate how unsettling and frustrating it can be for parents to not be able to find the products they need. We are working hard to get products back onto shelves as soon as possible. We are sending out supplies of Nutriprem  g products, and these should start to be available in stores towards the end of this week. Although this may y by store and region. We have good availability of our Nutriprem  ml liquid productwhich is also an option. In the meantime, we want to do everything we can to help. If Shannon would like to get in touch, we can help locate supplies or possible alternatives.
