title: unvaccinated nurse says prepared lose
story: Unvaccinated nurse says she is prepared to lose her job than have the Covid jabNHS frontline staff in England are required to be fully vaccinated by April  meaning they must have their first jab by early February or risk losing their jobsThe government measure means nurses must get the jab or risk losing their jobImage: AFP via Getty ImagesByMaria OkanrendeLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  An NHS nurse insisted she is prepared to risk her job rather than getting vaccinated against coronavirus. All frontline workers in England face the sackthey have not had two Covid vaccines by April , meaning they must get their first dose by February . The unvaccinated nurse, of London, told of her outrage at the mandate and called it an infringement of her human rights. How can you force me to put something in my body andI disagree then Iaposm out of a job and potentially lose my home  she told My London.I donapost know how Iaposm going to pay my mortgage, I donapost know how Iaposm going to pay my bills but itaposs a risk Iaposm willing to take for my human rights.  The nurse is based in the east London borough of Newham where  per cent of residents are yet to receive their first dose. She claims she was handed a letter from her employer stating that her team must be vaccinated by the end of March or leave their jobs. But the message has proven fruitless in persuading her to change her mind. As a healthcare professional I should be given the opportunity to make an informed decision about things affecting my body, she said. I hope someone somewhere will have common sense and bring about some sort of change. I thinkwe accept this then it opens a dangerous door to other things that the Government or other corporations can impose on our livelihoods. The nurse, who is of African descent, believes that vaccine hesitancy is strong in black and ethnic minority communities, and suggested reasons for this could be fear, hidden agendas and issues of mistrust.  Recent figures show that the  most unvaccinated areas in the UK are all in London. Almost one third of Londoners still have not received their first dose of the vaccine, according to Government data. Most of Londonaposs boroughs are lagging far behind other parts of the UK, with Westminster ranking worst overall for first dose uptake at just . per cent. By stark contrast, the five areas with the highest first dose vaccination rates in the UK are all in Scotland according to figures from January . Argyll and Bute is the most vaccinated upper tier local authority in the UK where . per cent of residents have had the first jab. Dr Raheelah Ahmad, director for global engagement at City, University of London, has studied vaccine uptake in England.We found that Asian and Black people are, respectively, twice and . times less likely to accept the Covid- vaccine than White British people, she said.The expert also highlighted the importance of analysing ethnic minority inclusion in the fight against vaccine hesitancy. Population characteristics can be used to infer vulnerability of certain communities to Covid, or to the likelihood of high levels of vaccine hesitancy, she added. Communities harder hit by the virus, or at risk of being so, stand to benefit from greater resource allocation than their population size alone would suggest. This could partly explain why the total number of people living in Newham who have received a first dose stands at almost  per cent lower than top-of-the-table Bromley. Bromley is the most vaccinated borough in London, with . per cent of residents receiving the first dose. Just  per cent of Bromleyaposs population consists of black and ethnic minority communities, while these same communities make up over  per cent of Newham, according to an ONS population census in . The London borough of Kensington and Cha is the second most unvaccinated UTLA in the UK where just . per cent of residents have had the first dose. Professor Azeem Majeed, chair in primary care and public health at Imperial College London, suggested that low vaccination rates among Londoners could also be driven by a mobile population. He said: With many living in the capital shorter term, for work or study, it can be dficult to send vaccine appointments because of inaccurate address information. For example, some Londoners will have had their vaccines overseas and won’t show up in official statistics. He added: “We need to continue to encourage people living in London and across the UK to get vaccinated and reduce their risk of catching COVID- and having a more serious illness.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON NHSUniversity of LondonImperial CollegeHuman rightsCoronavirus vaccineCoronavirusHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: what new rules working home
story: What are the new rules for working from home and can your company force you back in The Prime Minister announced the end to some Plan B restrictions as the government hopes the UK is past the peak of Omicron. Some people will still be wary about ing to workPlan B guidance is coming to and end and some has already been scrapped Image: Getty ImagesByBenjamin LynchSEO Writer:,  Jan | comments Rules for working from home have changed once again.Boris Johnsonaposs government announced the plan after its review into the Plan B restrictions in place since December, designed to slow the spread of the coronavirus.The government hopes that the UK is now past the peak of the Omicron iant, although the number of confirmed cases have gone back up again since an apparent downward trend at the beginning of this week.Reported cases on January  had fallen to ,, the lowest since December. However, over , cases were reported on January . This is still nowhere near the beginning of January, when cases were well over the , mark, but is not an encouraging sign as the government lts restrictions. Plan B brought in restrictions like working from home, so can we now go back into the office  Do we still have to work from home   Work-from-home guidance ended with immediate effect, the Prime Minister announced in a statement to the House of Commons on Wednesday, January . This means that people are now able to go back into the office when previously they were discouraged from doing so since Plan B was put in place on December .  The PM said: From now on, the government are no longer asking people to work from home. People should now speak to their employer about arrangements for ing to the office.Leader of the Labour PartyKeir Starmer said in response that the opposition approved the plans as long as they were based on evidence.He said the PM must reassure the public he is acting to protect their health, not just his job. Can your company force you to go back to the office   If your company requires you to come into the office, they can only make youyour contract stipulates working in an office. Citizens Advice said: You can ask to keep working from home, but that doesnapost mean your employer has to agree. Start by having an open conversation with your employer about your wishes, and consider making a flexible working request. However, employers are also duty-bound to make the work environment as safe as possible, so they should consider minimising visitors and improving ventilation, as well as considering the use of one-way systems and extra cleaning. The Trade Union Commission, meanwhile, had firmer advice people may want to considerthey do not feel safe at work.It said: If your boss is asking you toto the workplace or stay at home and you don’t feel comfortable, you should speak to other members and your union rep immediately - they may feel the same about the situation. If you raise the issue collectively with your employer, they’re much more likely to listen. What  has changed   Plan B restrictions were originally due to expire on January . As well as the work-from-home guidance, the PM announced that face coverings would no longer be required in school classrooms from January . An unnamed director of public health at a city in the north of England said they have some concerns about the change of rules in classrooms.They told: This feels like more of a political decision than a decision based on the evidence and the science, and it could be quite London-centric.I worry the decision has not been made for the right reasons. From January , face coverings in indoor public places will no longer be required and venues and events will no longer be required by law to use NHS Covid passes.Venues can choose to impose the use of passesthey choose to do so.Health and Social Care Secretary Sajid Javid said: Today marks the start of the next chapter in this country’s fight against [Covid].But it’s not the end of the road and we shouldn’t see this as the finish line. The best step that we can all take is to get vaccinated. title: woman makes 60k year driving
story: Woman makes £k-a-year driving for Uber and baking cakes after quitting jobKasey Clarke, , traded in her job as a producer at the BBC to start her own cake baking firm, while driving for Uber on the sideKasey Clarke took the plunge and quit her high-flying job at the BBC Image: Andor Ivan ByRachael Davis:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA woman who quit her high-flying BBC job to start a cake business now makes around £, a year and says she has no regrets. Kasey Clarke, , traded in her job as a producer to start her own firm.Kasey had worked at the BBC for  years before leaving in  to pursue baking full-time, MyLondon reports. She now runs her own successful business, Sweet Cakey Thing, which she launched in March  after spending years developing her craft and finding her niche - as well as driving for Uber in Central London on the side.These ventures combined make her up to £, a year, and she credits the flexibility of Uber for facilitating her success. In  I went full-time into baking, and financially I wasnapost  per cent prepared for that, Kasey said. I was able to keep myself going for a couple of years before I had to find another source of income to support me.I tried other avenues, working as a warehouse operative for John Lewis, as a pollster during the Brexit campaign, teaching cake decorating skills... but all of these things had the problem of being very fixed, in terms of time, in terms of income.I found juggling those very rigid timetables around impromptu cake orders very hard - I wanted to find something that was flexible to my primary needs of building my business. There are plenty of problems with the gig economy, but one thing that can be said for the likes of Uber is its flexibility. You can work when you want, where you want, and that prospect was very appealing to Kasey. I was doing the midnight sht at John Lewis, schlepping mattresses from one end of the warehouse to the other, and I kept hearing this advert for Uber. I was like: aposYou know what, I love driving, Iaposve never considered being a taxi driver before, and these guys seem to have made it really easy for me to do that. Let me look into itapos, she said. Kasey signed up for Uber, which enabled her to get her finances under control, sort out her credit score, and to be able to take on the sorts of baking jobs she really wanted to do.  Rather than keeping on churning out kidsapos birthday cakes, Kasey could start working on the beautul wedding cakes sheaposd always dreamed of, and then she started developing Sweet Cakey Thing. Sweet Cakey Thing is an award-winning naughty, natural, outrageous indulgence,  per cent aposfree fromapos cake in a jar, Kasey explains. Itaposs perfect for paleo, gluten intolerance, coeliacs, yogis, gym bunnies, and people who just want to enjoy a clean diet with absolutely no crap in there at all, just  per cent natural whole foods. Kasey spent the time leading up to the first Covid lockdown in her kitchen developing recipes, launching the brand at a yoga studio pop-up in March . Shortly afterwards, the country went into lockdown and Sweet Cakey Thing had to go entirely online. Kasey continued driving for Uber, which she says requires a great deal of management and responsibility in order to balance her business and her side hustle, but her earnings show how well it can pay off.  I start my day in Hertfordshire, where I am now, and I just go where the rides take me, she said. Iniably they take me into London, I find myself there almost every day. I tend to work less to an area and more to the clock: I clock in at six, with a view to doing six hours and be done by  so I can get back and focus on other things, getting to the kitchen or whatever needs to be done, she continued. Wherever I find myself around  oaposclock is where Iaposm looking to start making my way back towards home. Iaposm near Stansted Airport, but I find myself in East London, or South London, or West London, Central London pretty quickly. All roads lead to London, she laughed. Despite how much she loves driving for Uber, meeting new people every day and seeing every corner of London, Kasey hopes that  will be the year she can take Sweet Cakey Thing full time. Iaposm looking forward to building on where Iaposve got to in the past six months, expanding the range with new flavours, and Iaposm hoping to do a pop-up tour in the summer, she said. All of that means Iaposll be needing to spend more time with Sweet Cakey Thing and less time on the road. My TfL licence expires this August, and my agenda is to not need to review it, so come August Iaposll be a full-time entrepreneur, working on my cake business. Come August, itaposll just be aposthank you very muchapos to Uber for having gotten me to this point, for supporting me in building my dream. Dreams like Kaseyaposs are made by people shopping small and supporting local independent business, which is something many Londoners have been doing a lot more of throughout Covid. She hopes the sentiment continues as the world continues to open up again, and that people continue to shop small, and shop often. title: woman mortified after going through
story: Woman mortied after going through freebies in wedding fair goody bagRebekah, from Sittingbourne, Kent, was outraged after attending a wedding show as she was given a bag of freebies to take away with her but it contained a very outdated itemA woman named Rebekah took to Twitter after finding the offensive item Image: scuByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A woman was left aposmortiedapos after going through a bag of freebies given to her at a wedding fair - as it contained a diet cereal bar.The woman, known only as Rebekah, said she attended an event organised by The Wedding Experience and was hoping to pick up some hints and tips on how to best organise a marriage ceremony. She was given a goody bag and when she opened it she was outraged, as it contained a aposSkinny Rawapos breakfast bar, as she believe this implies brides need to diet before their big day.Rebekah took to Twitter to share her outrage at the event, held in Sittingbourne, Kent, and now the organiser has responded - defending their decision to include the item.Do you think the event organiser should have included the diet bar in the goody bag  Let us know in the comments...Rebekah said: Iaposm not the bride, Iaposm the maid of honour. We went to the wedding fair and I was slightly mortied they handed over four skinny bars, which personally I think is kinda wrong. I think it perpetuates a diet culture that I donapost think is needed. For me, itaposs more about the bar - itaposs a skinny brand, theyaposre advertising it as guilt-free, I think with everything that brides go through itaposs not a positive message to be sending. If youaposre going to put something in it, donapost choose something diet. I know itaposs just a gimmick but it can be damaging.  Itaposs insensitive, and itaposs pushing a diet culture to brides and reinforces that skinny complexanyone has had an eating disorder. Or it could create one. I donapost think it aligns with todayaposs body positivity.After attending the event, Rebekah took to Twitter to share her outrage. She wrote: I am absolutely mortied. I have just been to the wedding show in Detling Hill and received what I thought was a goody bag full of fun wedding hints and tips, instead, I find a diet bar.Read More Need I say more  In , do we really need to perpetuate the idea that brides need to diet  Tina Green, the companyaposs event director, said: We include a wide range of gts in our goody bags and last weekend this included snack bars, non-alcoholic cider and beauty vitamins, along with a selection of leaflets and magazines packed with wedding inspiration. The confectionery item is a high-protein low-calorie snack bar which the company describes as being designed for aposon-the-go snackersapos.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. It is not a meal replacement but simply a healthy and nutritious snack, so we have in no way suggested brides and grooms focus on weight loss. In recent shows weaposve included items such as popcorn, milkshakes, orange juice, body lotion, chocolate truffles, toothpaste, sunscreen and many other erse products. Not all of our free gts will suit every bride and groom but hopefully there is something interesting for everyone to enjoy after their visit to The Wedding Experience.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: woman rides horse through mcdonalds
story: Woman rides a HORSE through McDonalds drive-thru leaving customers baffledDrivers were understandably baffled when a woman on a steed joined the line of vehicles waiting to order food from a McDonalds drive-thru in Borehamwood, HertsDrivers were baffled when they saw this woman and her horse line up with other vehicles at a McDonalds drive-thru near Borehamwood, England Image: SplashNewsByBen BlochAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments These hilarious snaps have captured a horse rider ordering McDonaldaposs from the drive-thru on her steed. The incredible scenes were snapped at one of the fast-food chainaposs restaurants in Borehamwood, Herts.Normally, drivers in cars are seen ordering grub from the drive-thru, but many were understandably left baffled when a woman and her steed joined the line of vehicles waiting.When she got to the window, she dismounted and told the employee what she wanted, Bristol Livereports. Her horseaposs snout was then seen hilariously poking its snout curiously into the window - probably trying to inspect the aromas of McDonaldaposs food. The woman was then seen trotting on with a coffee in one hand as she chatted away on her mobile phone. It is unclear whether she ordered any food for her steed or decided to keep their diet to carrots and hay. Incredibly, it is not the first time McDonaldaposs customers have seen someone ordering from the drive-thru on horseback.In December, dad-of-three Simon White saw the hilarious event unfold while stopping to eat at his local McDonaldaposs in Caerphilly, Wales. The woman stood in the queue, paid at the first window and then collected her meal at the second while Simon,  took some photos of the bizarre incident. His pictures show the woman in a mustard puffer jacket and riding boots sitting on a white horse and joining the line as though nothing is out of the ordinary. She holds her purse in her hand, ready to pay for her snack, and then pays for her food while perched on her horse. The horse appeared to not be phased and waited for her to finish patiently, and the two rode off after the staff members give her her meal. Simon a vehicle parts constructor, said: I was on my way home from collecting my little one from school when we stopped by for something to eat. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.We were sitting there waiting for our food when she came round the corner. I couldnapost believe it - the horse was very well-behaved though and she got served no problem, before riding off. A few of the kids who were sitting inside came out to take pictures and cheer her as they thought it was great. He added: She was served and rode off. Then I passed her on the road where she was eating the burger. My son loved it, it really made his day - he was laughing so much. I thought it was really funny as well - itaposs something you just canapost imagine seeing unless you live in the Welsh valleys. title: women can peace mind safest
story: Women can have peace of mind with safest mix of HRT in battle against dementiaSide-effect scares have put many women off taking hormone replacement therapy, writes the Mirrors Dr Miriam Stoppard, but new trials are putting its links to dementia into contextA new study shows the risk depends on progesterone Image: Getty Images Collection Mix: Subjects RFopinionByMiriam Stoppard:,  Jan | commentsSince its arrival, hormone replacement therapy has been controversial. Side effects such as thrombosis caused alarm and women to reject it. Then scares about breast cancer further eroded their confidence. Emanating from the Women’s Health Initiative Memory Study , concerns about the risk of dementia with HRT has grown.The first study showed dementia doubled in women aged  years and older after taking a particular form of combined HRTfor an average of four years.However, a later report from that study found no increased risk of dementia with equine oestrogens alone, whereas pooled results of both formulations showed a % increased risk. WHIMS had been the only large-scale trial of HRT for the prevention of dementia. Trials of HRT and cognitiveamong women in early menopause showed neutral results. According to Yana Vinogradova of Nottingham University, and colleagues from Chicago and Boston, key questions remain. Does oestrogen have greater cognitive safety than oestrogen and progestogen combined  Does timing or duration of use, or both, matter  Can the WHIMS findings apply to women in early menopause or to those using other hormone products A new large studyattempts to answer those questions. An important, surprising finding is the risk of dementia doesn’t depend on oestrogen but on progesterone. Oestrogen alone conferred a % decreased odds of dementia among women younger than  who were treated for at least  years, with a % decrease in risk for each year of treatment. Conversely, when oestrogen and progestogen were combined there was an % increased risk of Alzheimer’s and dementia among women who had used hormone therapy for five to nine years. And there was a % increased risk among women treated for  years or more. When , women treated with conjugated equine oestrogens alone were followed for  years they ended up with a % decreased risk of death from Alzheimer’s and dementia.Crucially, this risk wasn’t altered when conjugated oestrogens were combined with medroxyprogesterone acetate. Of all the combinations, oestrogen-dydrogesterone used for one to  years, carried the lowest risk. This combo is special – in earlier studies, it had the lowest risk for breast cancer and thrombosis.These findings don’t mean HRT should be used to prevent dementia. But for anyone taking HRT it puts dementia into context. No increase in risk was found with oestrogen alone, and, for oestrogen plus progesterone, the increased risk was five to seven extra cases per , woman years. news us-news man--gets-two-pig-"US medics make history with pig heart transplant into patientByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Two pig kidneys have been transplanted into a human in a world-first operation.US scientists showed the organs worked for more than three days during an experiment on a brain dead patient called Jim Parsons. The -year-old already on articial le support was a registered organ donor and his family had agreed to the pioneering op on his behalf. Surgeons say within a decade other pig organs such as hearts, lung and livers could be given to humans needing transplants.  Senior author Dr Jayme Locke, of the University of Alabama at Birmingham, said: “This game-changing moment in the history of medicine represents a paradigm sht and a major milestone in the field of xenotransplantation, which is arguably the best solution. “We have bridged critical knowledge gaps and obtained the safety and feasibility data necessary to begin a clinical trial in living humans with end-stage kidney failure disease.” It comes weeks after the first pig heart was transplanted into a living US patient and three months after the first single kidney was transplanted in to another brain dead patient.  In this latest op ten key genes that would have led to the kidneys being rejected were knocked out in the genetically modied donor pig. Mr Parsons’ ex-we Julie O’Hara, and their children, Ally, David and Cole, made the decision, along with his sisters and mother.  Ms O’Hara said: “Jim was a never-met-a-stranger kind of guy who would talk to anyone and had no enemies - none. “Jim would have wanted to save as many people as he could with his death, andhe knew he could potentially save thousands and thousands of people by doing this, he would have had no hesitation. “Our dream is that no other person dies waiting for a kidney, and we know that Jim is very proud that his death could potentially bring so much hope to others.” Kidney disease kills more people each year than breast or prostate cancer and pig organs could soon be given to patients suffering end-stage kidney failure.  Mr Parsons’ family gave permission for the four hour procedure to go ahead at the university’s Legacy of Hope Donor Recovery Centre. The kidneys filtered blood, produced urine and, importantly, were not immediately rejected. They remained viable until the study was ended,  hours after transplant. Mr Parsons was a registered organ donor. He had longed to have his organs help others upon his death - but they were not suitable. So he was maintained on a ventilator to keep his body ing. His native kidneys were removed, and replaced with the pig’s. Dr Locke said: “Mr Parsons and his family allowed us to replicate precisely how we would perform this transplant in a living human. “Their powerful contribution will save thousands of lives, and that could begin in the very near future. “Mr Parsons’ gt honours his legacy and firmly establishes the viability, safety and feasibility of this preclinical model. Because of his gt, we have proposed this to be known as ‘The Parsons Model.’” The Food and Drug Administration in the US has approved the use of genetic modication of pigs for this type of research. However rules in the UK are much stricter and would currently prohibit such work. It involves the setting up of specialist facilities where pigs can be bred genetically modied to tweak, silence and add key genes that would reject key organs such as the heart and kidney. The results pave the way for a Phase  clinical trial at Alabama for patients with end-stage kidney failure. Dr Locke added: “A radical solution is needed for the organ supply crisis. The domestic pig is a promising organ source.” Pig heart valves are already widely used in humans. The natural lespan of a pig is  years, they are easily bred and have organs of similar size. Genetically modied pig kidneys have been extensively tested in non-human primates. The Mirror has campaigned for six years to increase organ donation and successfully lobbied the Government to introduce a “deemed consent” system in England in .The NHS Blood and Transplant says matching more human donors remains the priority for now.A spokesperson said: “There is still some way to go before transplants of this kind become an everyday reality. “While researchers and clinicians continue to do our best to improve the chances for transplant patients, we still need everyone to make their organ donation decision and let their family know what they want to happenorgan donation becomes a possibility.” The findings are reported in the American Journal of Transplantation. news us-news woman-sheds-massive-st-after-"Woman loses seven stone to try find a wedding dress that fitsByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A woman has lost seven stone after finding love and being desperate to find a wedding dress that fits.Meredith Hutson, , was left devastated after trying on wedding dresses following her engagement and finding they wouldnapost zip up due to her weight.Meredith - who weighed st lb at her heaviest - set to work on losing weight in August  with just over a year to go until her wedding to now husband Steven Hutson, , and now weighs st lb.By her wedding day in November  , Meredith had lost st lb and fit into her wedding dress but she didnapost stop there, as she went on to lose another four stone and dropped eight dress sizes. Meredith, who works as a hairdresser and fitness coach, went from a dress size of  to a dress size of six in the space of two years. Meredith, from Texas, US, said: My whole le I was overweight and no matter what fad diet I tried, I would lost a little bit and then after a few months I would give up and gain it all back plus extra.When I was , I was faced with serious health issues and was concerned about my overall health and future given my weight so everyday, I was suffering from headaches, rashes, nausea, and doctors could never find a problem besides a thyroid condition.One day, I realised my health had reached this low point because of my weight and thataposs when I made the decision to start my weight loss journey. After getting engaged, the wedding motivated me to lose weight because when I was dress shopping, I had trouble fitting in dresses or doing the zip up at several stores. It was really discouraging but by my wedding day, I felt beautul and although I wasnapost at my goal weight, I was so proud of what I had accomplished. My husband has supported me so much on this journey and heaposs always encouraged me to stay on track. Meredith first started losing weight by joining a gym in August  and changing her eating habits. The fitness fanatic went from weighing st lb to st lb in just two years and is now helping others do the same. She added: In a little over two years, I lost all of that weight whilst gaining muscle mass from simply counting my macros and eating in the correct calorie deficit along with weight training six days a week. My sizes changed completely I went from a XL to a small in clothes and my bra size went from a DDD to a B. I started posting on social media when I first started losing weight and the support I was getting from others was amazing so I pushed even harder and shared more to show others that it could be done.  I then started giving others advice at that point and then found a true passion in helping others. My husband cooks for us daily and at the beginning of my journey, he worked away from home so he would spend his days teaching me everything nutrition wise so I was able to cook the right food for myself when he was away. I am still in the process of transforming my body and am still currently in a calorie deficit as of now. Although I am way pass my goal, my plan is to stay in a deficit for a little bit longer to target certain stubborn areas and then in a few months I will be doing a small bulk to strictly gain muscle mass. title: brits left stitches over cheeky
story: Brits left in stitches over cheeky window design that resembles something rudeThe wonderful people of Reddit have been left in stitches after someone shared a photo of a rather rude looking window overlooking a cemetery in Banbury, OxfordshireDont pretend you cant see it... Image: RedditByLayla NicholsonEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments If you were ever in any doubt over just how immature British humour is, then look no further than this thread of Brits left in fits of giggles over a rather rude looking window. Youaposve got to admit, it is pretty funny.Swaths of Brits have been left in stitches after someone on Reddit highlighted an unusual window design, which,youaposve got a rather cheeky mind, looks an awful lot like the shape of a penis.According to the Daily Star, the window appears on a lodge overlooking a cemetery in Banbury, Oxfordshire, and many people have been left gobsmacked at its phallic-like appearance. Told you, immature humour. Anyway, the body of the window is impressive inand consists of four panes – with the top piece of glass moulded into a rounded tip. The design also boasts a girthy exterior with a circular window on each side. Reddit users have been left in stitches at the phallic windows, and so took to the comments to poke fun at the construction.I see nothing wrong here, seems like a perfectly normal wangdow to me, one joked, while another added: Every time we drove past this to visit my grandma I would giggle at this. A third commented: The builders must have had fun when they erected it… We see what you did there. Ahaha the glorious d*** window that sits right by a cemetery...classic, a fourth wrote, while another said: I hope Iaposm not the only one who can see the two windows below look like a pair of legs, parted and waiting…Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news weird-news craig-charles-believes-ufos-clearly-"UFO Conspiracies: Trailer for new show with Craig CharlesByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsRed Dwarf star Craig Charles has said he believesUFOs definitely exist and that heaposs seen one - as he hosts a new documentary about the phenomenon. The actor, presenter, comedian, author, and DJ is truly a Jack of all trades and now heaposs fronting a Sky History show that examines famous sightings, called UFO : Conspiracies.Craig, , said that UFOs can come in aposall dferent shapes and sizesapos, and heaposs opened up about his own spooky sighting. He said he isnapost sure what was behind the phenomenon, but on the documentary he examines evidence alongside expert astrophysicist and award-winning author Sarah Cruddas to try to get to the bottom of it.  What do you think about UFOs  Let us know in the comments...Craig became a national favourite when he starred as David Lister in hit comedy Red Dwarf, where he was, mostly, the last human alive, floating through space and encountering aliens. Craig said that his interest in UFOs, also known as Unidentied Aerial Phenomenabegan in those early days, but he was afraid to admit it. Speaking to Sky History, he said: Back in the day you would never say so because people would think you were a bit of a crank. Now, the Americans have released all this footage that clearly shows these UFOs, and UAPs are there. Iaposm not saying theyaposre not aliens but they do exist. What are they   Do the Russians and Chinese have technology that is so much more advanced from our own  That is as frightening as aliens to be sure. How can craft travel , mph then stop instantly  The G-Force alone from that would turn a human being into mush  Are they drones, or are they robots  Some of them fly and then go underwater. We have footage of that from fighter jets and aircraft carriers. What are they  Me and my friend were in Galway once, sat in his garden and these weird things flew over. The next day, there was like, lots of stuff on the news about it. People had been phoning in to report seeing alien craft flying over the skies of Galway. Me and my mate saw that but I donapost know what it was   Working alongside Sarah on the TV show, Craig is examining famous sightings and they look at a sleepy Welsh village thataposs the scene of a major sighting, evidence collected from a aposcrash siteapos, and rumours of a military cover up. Craig said: The Rendlesham Forest case is really interesting because it was the American military who reported seeing all these weird lights in the woods. These are highly trained officers who arenapost going to mistake a car headlight for a spaceship. You do wonder what they actually saw there. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. A lot of the footage thataposs just been released by the American Air Force is very compelling. You can see these things on film and theyaposre all dferent shapes. A lot of people report seeing this pyramid-shaped craft. It doesnapost have an engine and itaposs just thrusting forward and flying through the air. This pyramid shape comes up quite a lot, from many dferent sightings. Thereaposs a lot of dferent kind of craft that people have claimed to see: barrel-shaped, disc-shaped and boomerang-shaped craft.  Unfortunately, with this series, hard evidence is really thin on the ground and thataposs one thing I found a bit frustrating. Although all of the stories are told with conviction and are certainly very believable He added: I now know that these things exist. Theyaposre not a figment of anyoneaposs imagination. Even the American government admits that now. Itaposs proved to me that Iaposm not a Fraggle. Unexplained Aerial Phenomena are out there, we just donapost know what they are. Sarah Cruddas added: “We are living in an incredible time for space exploration, but we are only just beginning to scratch the surface of what is out there. Marrying together Craig’s passion and enthusiasm with my own thirst for evidence and an application of science, we have been able to explore what is going on in our skies like never before. Some of the answers are likely to be stranger than anything you could ever imagine.” Craig Charles: UFO Conspiracies aired on January  on Sky History. The channel is available on Sky , NOW, Virgin  and Talk Talk  All episodes will be available on catch up servicesDo you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: dad asks amazon message princess
story: Dad asksAmazon message from Princess Diana is a joke - but its workers real nameA dad was baffled after being greeted by Princess Diana on Amazons customer service app and initially wonderedhed stumbled across some sort of Royal conspiracyJames was baffled by the Amazon workers name Image: Kennedy News and MediaByJulia BanimSophie Norris:,  Jan | commentsAfter an Amazon order for his young sonaposs space hopper resulted in a bit of delivery confusion, James Brand was forced to contact the retail giantaposs customer service team for assistance. However, after hopping on Amazonaposs customer service chat on Tuesday to alert them to the toy having been delivered, the -year-old scientist was somewhat surprised to find himself being greeted by one of the most famous women of the th century: the late Princess Diana. After clocking the name of the rep he was speaking with, James, who had been on the train home from work at the time, couldnapost help but laugh, sending a screenshot of the image to his we Alison - before joking aposis Diana actually dead - or working for Amazon apos  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. James, of Rainhill, Merseyside, said: When I saw it I had a giggle to myself. Is this something we donapost know about Amazon  Is [Diana] actually dead  Did she fake her death and is she working at Amazon When I joined the chat and spoke to the chatbot it put me through to the advisor and thataposs what came up.Itaposs just a weird name for someone to have on the chat. I just thought it was a bit funny so I screenshotted it. He continued: I think theyaposd given themselves that nickname on the chat because when Iaposve spoken to advisors in the past, theyaposve just been normal names like Sophie. Obviously, Iaposm not sure where theyaposre based oritaposs even in the UK, but I think maybe somebody did it as a joke or theyaposd just changed it. Although declining to give further comment, Amazon has since confirmed the name is indeed real, however, it doesnapost appear that James was actually chatting with the beloved Peopleaposs Princess.In the Philippines, aposPrincessapos has ranked amongst the most popular baby names in recent years, whether or not the bearer has any royal lineage. James revealed that his we had been left equally tickled by his regal encounter: I showed the message to my we and she laughed when she saw it. She said aposwhyaposs someone put that as their username apos Friends have had the same reaction, they laughed and said it was a strange name. I shared it with a couple of friends on WhatsApp. Have you had an interesting or surprising customer service experience  Email us at yourmirror@mirror Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AmazonPrincess DianaAppsRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ex primark employee shares store
story: Ex-Primark employee shares store secrets - like where to find hidden stockEx-Primark employee Georgia has built a following of more than , fans on TikTok with her videos exposing company secrets - like what to do when the item you want is out of stockGeorgia used to work in Primark while she went to college Image: @pontasaurus TikTokByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsA former Primark employee has shared a number of store secrets that customers might not know about. Georgia Pontin from Kettering in Northamptonshire first started working for the clothing giant on the weekends after college, back in July .During her time there she learnt a thing or two about the running of the store and a number of insider secrets, which she now shares on her TikTok @pontasaurus .Georgia first went viral on the app after she posted a video revealing what it was like working there and the best ways to shop in the store as a customer. Since then she has posted  more videos on the subject, growing her a following of more than , fans. So, we have compiled some of her best store secrets, so you can get the most bang for your buck. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Why the clothes are so cheap Primark is loved for its bargains, but apparently, thereaposs a reason why the clothes are so cheap. Georgia explained that the store doesnapost play any music to keep costs down. By not playing music they donapost have to pay any licensing fees which helps keep the cost down, and to be fair Primark is loud enough as it is so you wouldnapost even hear the music, she said. Where to find hidden stock Georgia explained how both staff and shoppers would hide their favourite pieces in strange locations around the store when new releases arrived, as these items quickly run out of popular sizes. However, most customers forget they put these items away – so itaposs always worth a look whereyouaposre struggling to find a size. The ex-employee recommends starting with corners of the shop and lower racks, especially in the nightwear section. All the popular stuff goes very quickly, she said. The most popular sizes, which are ,  and  will go and once theyaposre gone, theyaposre gone. But sometimes people are undecided about a piece of clothing and will hide it in case they want to come back and get it. They almost always forget about it but sometimesyou check right at the back of the rails that are still quite full, some people hide stuff there. And in corners of the store. Since a lot of people glance over areas that are in front of them, the corners of the store are sometimes the most forgotten about. There was one particular corner in the pyjama section, on the lowest rack, where people would hide stuff. When I used to work and I saw something I want to buy on my break, I would put it in that corner too and come and collect it when I was on my break. Donapost worry, Iaposm pretty sure my managers knew I did that. It was so hard to not spend all your money in there since we worked around the clothes all the time and saw the items as they first hit the shelves. What to doyour size isnapost in stock Itaposs so annoying when you find something you like but you canapost find it in your size. While many of us might just accept that itaposs not meant to be, there is something  you can do. Georgia said: If you find something you really like but they donapost have your size in stock at one store, then you can ask one of the members of staff to call another store and seethey have it. Obviously you would have to go and pick it up, they wonapost deliver it to the store but itaposs something to think about. Now thereaposs no guarantee that a staff member is going to do it for you, but itaposs always best to checkyou really want this product. Why you should wash the clothes before you wear them This one isnapost so much of a secret Georgia says, but an important reminder. When you buy your clothes and you take them home, please wash them the first time you wear them. Like every other retail store,someoneaposs ing something or theyaposve tried something on in the fitting room, it doesnapost get washed after theyaposve tried it on. You have no clue what that other person has been doing, what theyaposve been wearing, where theyaposve put their clothes - so please wash the clothes. Sometimes when I used to work there, weaposd get clothes back and weaposd check them over and they had stains on them and only then we can determine whether we sell it or not. If we choose not to sell it then it would go to the faulty bit butwe do sell it, then itaposll be a reduced price - so thataposs the risk that you have to take. What the bells mean If you ever hear three rings on the bell, be careful – it signals that there is some form of emergency going on. Georgia said: The bells ringing in Primark have dferent meanings. One ring is to alert the floor staff that help is needed on the tills, two rings are to alert supervisors and site managers, and three rings is to signal for an emergency. Despite some unfortunate experiences with unhappy customers, Georgia thoroughly enjoyed working at Primark. She added: I loved working at Primark. My first job as a waitress was awful and put me off working in food forever. When I heard a Primark was opening up at the new shopping complex, I jumped at the chance. Since I started from the beginning, everyone was in the same boat and we all saw what the store looked like without any clothes or stock in. They brought in staff from all over the country to help us set up so we knew what we were doing. How to get first dibs on clothes in a new store If you have a new Primark store opening up in your area, this is how to get first dibs on the clothes in there, Georgia says. So I started working at my store when it first ever opened and we had a staff only night just before it opened. You got to see it brand new, you got to see all the new stock, you got first dibs on the popular items and all the popular sizes... At the event, you can bring friends and family so they can see everything too and they can buy stuff first as well. Soyou have a new store opening up and you know someone thataposs gonna work there then thataposs how to get first dibs on all the items in the shop. When to avoid shopping Georgia explained that each store has a prime time which is their busiest hour. So at the store I worked at, our prime time was pm and during that time, anyone who wasnapost on break or lunch had to be downstairs on the shop floor. Because it got so busy we had to go behind everyone and fold everything, put things back and make sure it was all neat, or at least weaposd try to. Often during that time thataposs when the queue is longest. While queueing is inevitable, Georgia suggests going during off-peak periods so you can get served quicker.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: i saved hundreds pounds each
story: I love living on a barge, London prices are ridiculous and it feels like were outsideA -year-old man has revealed the drastic s he went to while looking for a new home in a bid to avoid extortionate rents and the pricey London housing marketLloyd in the renovated kitchen area Image: MERCURY PRESSByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A bloke who has managed to save thousands while living in London has shared his unusual way of avoiding forking out for a pricey room.-year-old man Lloyd Seaman, a business development executive from Northern Ireland, was gobsmacked by the costs of living in London after moving. After forking out £ a month for a houseshare in central London, he decided to see what other options there were to avoid extortionate rents.But with London property prices even higher - he decided to use his savings to buy a -year-old Dutch narrowboat for £, in September .He then spent over a year doing renovations for an extra £, including labour costs, and now lives on the water in Cookham, Berks.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Along with his girlfriend, Ellie Williams, , he pays a £ mooring fee a month, along with a boating licence and insurance for roughly an additional £ per month. The average selling price of a flat within central London is well over £ million, meaning the couple has saved a huge fortune by investing in a home on the water.Lloyd said: “Renting in London was just ridiculous, I was paying £ a month for a room in a house share, and wouldnapost know where to begin with the price to buy outright.It made more sense for me to buy a barge to live on. Mooring at Cookham costs £ monthly, plus a boating licence and insurance for roughly an additional £ per month.“After that, the only other major running cost is coal for the stove, big bags are less than £ which usually lasts a few weeks.It isnapost just utility bills Lloyd saves on, but the renovation too.Lloyd managed to save on some labour costs by doing a lot of the work himself with the support of friends and family.He adds: “I had a welder install an extension on the stern and bow to give us more space, as well as creating that open plan effect.“I stripped the entire boat back to the metal frame, I was a bit hesitant at first, but with it being such an old boat, I wanted to make sure it was completely rust and rot free.“I had all the windows replaced with double glazing and installed a skylight for £ as well as painting the inside of the boat white to make the boat look airy and bright.“All of the frames and walls I constructed myself, as well as the bed but had to do a lot of shuffling around when I got the  litre water tank installed.“There were plenty of ups and downs during the renovations, and I definitely learned several new skills.“All the hard work has definitely paid off, I love the freedom that boat le gives you.”Despite the high cost of renovations, the couple have managed to snag a few bargains and freebies along the way.Ellie, an accountant from Derbyshire, said: “We bought a fridge on Facebook Marketplace for £, which fits everything we need and is certainly an upgrade from Lloyd’s original wine fridge. We also got some spare mattresses from friends that we turned into cushions with plenty of comfy filling.“We have a charity shop coffee table for working from home, but we’re hoping to build a proper workstation from scratch soon.“We both really love plants, so have filled the boat up with them, creating plant pots with old painted food tins.“Lloyd’s mum also gted us some lovely small painted decorative pieces.Lloyd added: “With the plants, skylight and open plan space, it really feels like we’re living outside. How do you save money  Let us know: mirror.money.saving@mirrorAfter living in ‘Julia’ for just under a year, the couple has had to make a series of compromises due to their minimalist living.Lloyd said: “It was definitely hard making the transition from living in a house share to living on a boat.“We’re completely reliant on solar power, so try and keep the fridge off with fewer daylight hours during winter, because they don’t charge up so quickly. We put things in a cool box instead.“Shower time also has to be limited as we’re not plugged into a water supply and we try not to use the washing machine on board.Ellie added: “I rent a flat in London for the time-being, so we pop in there every so often with all our laundry. “We’ll definitely miss that luxurywe both commit to living on the barge full-time.“I really miss having long showers, and they usually have to be less than two minutes so Lloyd will jokingly put a little egg timer on whilst I’m in there.Despite the compromises the pair have had to make, they have both fallen in love with river living and are looking forward to travelling around come summer, before eventually selling up.Lloyd said: “It’s incredible waking up on the river every morning and embracing the sounds of nature as well as viewing the sunrises.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON House pricesproperty news" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news weird-news man-claims-trick-making-perfect-"TikToker the Toastie King gives fans an unconventional hackByBrogan-Leigh HurstShowbiz Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A man on TikTok claims he has found the number one hack to making the perfect toastie - and fans absolutely love it.Itaposs no secret there are many iations on how to create the best version of the cheese toastie on the app, as many social media fans have tried and tested their own. But one user, in particular, is obsessed with his version of the hearty winter snack - and it would appear others are impressed, too.Scottish cook Toastie King, who has made plenty of iations of the dish - using Greggs sausage rolls, Wotsits and pigs in blankets - rustled up his perfect toastie in the kitchen, and the video has since gone viral with over k likes. He revealed his favourite way to make a toastie is to start by adding a thin layer of cheese, which creates a barrier for the bread so it doesnapost burn.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.Naming the TikTok video Toastie Hack #, he shared the process of how he perfected the delicious snack.The home cook explains the first step is to add cheese to the bottom of the toastie machine before adding a slice of bread. Itaposs then time to add your fillings before adding another slice of bread on top. Toastie King tells followers to let the bread toast for a few minutes, before adding another layer of cheese and letting it cook again for another few minutes. And the finished result sees a crispy toastie with a gooey, cheesy middle.  His fans were obsessed with his inventive way of making the perfect toastie, with many flocking to the comments section. One person wrote: Mmmm must try that! Another shared: Best TikTok Iaposve ever seen! While a third echoed: Nice hack! But others were left ided by the cleaning that comes with adding cheese to the toastie machine. And then spend two weeks trying to clean it off, a person commented. Another penned: And never be able to scrape it off. But the Toastie King revealed another clever hack - explaining as long as the toastie machine wasnapost scratched it is easy to come off as the oil from the cheese makes it easy to wipe down. It seems his idea will be used by many as it circulated on the app.Do you have a foodie story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: mum sparks debate after admits
story: Mum sparks debate after she admits her kids fly in business classTravel blogger and mum, Alexis sparked a debate amongst users on TikTok after she posted a video of her children flying first class as some people said they should be allowedAlexis kids fly first class Image: tiktok @worldtraveladventurersByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA mum has gone viral online after she posed a question about whether children be allowed to travel in business and first-class on planes. American blogger and mum, Alexis often shares videos of her travels, useful tips and destination recommendations on TikTok, where sheaposs known as @worldtraveladventurers. But in a recent video, that has been viewed more than , times, she sparked a debate about travel etiquette as she asked what the right age is for kids to be allowed in upper classes on planes. Do you think kids should be allowed to fly business class  she captioned the post. The video shows her two children, Ellie and Christophe, flying first class on a number of trips.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. If parents can buy them a seat in business class, then they have the right to be there, she says in the video. We do think itaposs important though, for parents to teach kids to have proper behaviour on flights. Alexis explains that they didnapost travel in premium cabins until her kids were at least four years old because at that age, they had more self-control and could manage their behaviour better. Flying in business class gives her kids the freedom to lie down, sleep, play games and watch films - and the other passengers rarely even know theyaposre there. She posed the controversial question to TikTok users, who were keen to give their opinion. Since being posted, the video has racked up almost , likes and  comments from ided viewers, with some saying they shouldnapost be allowed.One person said: Absolutely not. They should create a childrenaposs suite. Another added: I think Iaposd be madI saw them. Kids arenapost as quiet as parents pretend to think they are.While a third said: You didnapost understand the assignment. They should have appropriate behaviour in any section. But a few people didnapost see the problem.Greatthey can act like quiet adults, wrote one person.A second put: Honestly eventhey donapost behave you bought the tickets, they have the right to be there.Another wrote: WellI buy a ticket my child is next to me. No way Iaposm sitting in st and sheaposs where. I mean there are full-grown adults that didnapost know how to act on an aircraft sooo, said someone .There were also a few horror stories about babies ruining flights, like this one: I recently flew first class home from Hawaii and there was an infant who cried  screamed the entire way. Itaposs a lot of [money] to have to listen to that. What do you think  Should kids be allowed to fly first class  Let us know in the comments. Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-hailed-absolute-icon-after-"Shrek fan gets tattoo of sound waves for All StarByJulia Banim:,  Jan | commentsTymarah Emily Shandaposs friends have long joked about her enduring love for Shrek, the  aposanti-fairytaleapos about a grumpy ogre who learns to open up his heart and swamp to others after venturing on a reluctant quest.However, nobody could have guessed that the -year-old would declare her devotion for the iconic Dreamworks film in such a lasting fashion, opting to have a Spoty code inked on her arm in tribute.For those whoaposve never heard of such a thing, a Spoty Code is a QR-like tag that you can scan to access tracks within Spoty. So when Tymarahaposs arm is scanned with a phone, All-Star - which die-hard fans will recall plays out as we get to know Shrek and his grouchy bachelor lestyle in the opening credits - will play out on Spoty.Thankfully, it works perfectly. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Tymarah from Greenhithe, Kent said: I thought it was so funny and it actually worked! I just think the song and film is hilarious.Personally, I donapost think Iaposll regret it. I have quite a lot of tattoos and itaposs just a few lines on the back of my arm. Iaposve seen far worse tattoos on people! Shrek-mad Tymarah first saw the comedy adventure at the cinema as a child and declares she has been obsessed ever since, much to her friendsapos amusement. The eyelash technician explained: Itaposs kind of like an ongoing joke between me and my friends that I like Shrek. I think we spoke about getting a Shrek tattoo once and whenever we are on a long drive I just play the song. I thought this would be better than a Shrek tattoo as it means something to me and my friends, not just a random Shrek tattoo! Tymarah had the unusual tat done at Sacred Empire Tattoo  Piercing in Tonbridge on Friday, January th. Sheaposd initially booked in to have a Japanese dragon inked on her forearm, however, before getting out of the chair, she askedthe artist could also throw add the small Spoty Code tattoo on her upper arm.  Although it took a four-hour session to complete her dragon tattoo, it took just ten minutes for the artist, who is also a friend of Tymarah, to add the usable code. The artist made a stencil using a code Tymarah herself had screenshotted from her Spoty app. According to Tymarah: She knows Iaposm crazy so she didnapost even blink an eyelid! If they change the software and it doesnapost work I wouldnapost care, itaposs a personal tattoo on my body and means something to me. I have other amazing art pieces tattooed on me and they donapost have any meaning, soanything Iaposm more likely to regret them than a tattoo with meaning.Tymarah believes that the ink will serve as a reminder of my group of friends and our humour, remarking that lots of people get matching tattoos with friends. Looking ahead to the future, she added: I think it will be so funny to explain to my kids or grandkids what the tattoo is for and play them the song. So many people have tattoos about movie or TV characters, I personally donapost think this is any dferent. Tymarah has since posted a vid of her getting the tattoo on her TikTok, @itstymarah, clocking up almost k likes at the time of writing.The video said: When you definitely just made the best decision of your le... Tell me Iaposm wrong  If every comment is youaposre wrong Iaposm going to die LOL. Thankfully there was plenty of support in the comments, with even the official Spoty account commenting to declare you are an ALL-STAR. Reflecting on how she felt about any potential criticism of her body art, Tymarah reasoned: Personally I think people get super sensitive about other peopleaposs tattoos, itaposs not on your body so why would you care  Have you opted for a funny or unusual tattoo Get in touch. title: woman sickened after cleaning home
story: Woman sickened after cleaning home she inherited from parentsCandice Leigh Clark inherited her parents home after they passed away but she was sickened when she started cleaning up, as they were smokers who got through two packs a dayCandice Leigh Clark was sickened after inheriting a home from her parents Image: tiktok @candygirlByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman was apossickenedapos after inheriting a house from her parents - as they were smokers who got through two packs a day and the walls were thick with grime. TikTok star Candice Leigh Clark, @candygirl, shared a video online that showed her cleaning her parentsapos old house, which is now hers.She said that when she went to wipe the walls, the cloth she used was instantly covered in a thick layer of brown grime, and the clean area had changed colour - indicating the whole wall was covered in the muck. Candice then went on to say how her parents were smokers and would constantly light up inside, and now sheaposs urged others not to do the same.  What do you think about smoking in the house  Let us know in the comments...Candice captioned her video never smoke in the house, then added: My parents smoked two packs a day in their house! Candiceaposs video soon had over , views and nearly a hundred comments, mostly from people agreeing that smoking in the house was a bad idea. One said: That’s how my grandparentsapos fridge was! I just always thought it was like a tan-ish colour. Then I was wiping it after my grandma died and woah! Then a second added: Same here. My mum smoked a pack and didnapost clean nothing, Iaposm cleaning all the wall and doors cause I canapost take it anymore looks two shades lighter.  And a third replied: My mum smoked in the house and Iaposm currently going through the same thing. I donapost think people realise how bad smoke is in the house, wrote a fourth. Until you start cleaning it! Sugar soap is meant to be good!Meanwhile, a woman was gobsmacked after soaking her hoover pipe for the first time as the results were very grim - and now others are rushing to do it too. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere.Taking to Facebook, Rachael Stammers said she had a Henry Vacuum and in the three years she owned it she never thought about cleaning the inside of the pipe.Then one day she heard about the technique so thought sheaposd give it a go, and she was amazed by the results - as the water that came out was a disgusting colour and an oily residue rose to the top. She shared a photo of the results in the Facebook group Family Lowdown Tips and Ideas and soon others were saying that they would soon be trying it too.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: worlds shortest iq test only
story: Worlds shortest IQ test only has three questions - but  percent fail itIf you love a quiz, weve got the perfect one for you to try your hand at - its the shortest IQ test in the world, comprising of just three questions - but fewer than one in five get it rightCan you pass the worlds shortest IQ test Image: GettyByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Jul Updated:,  Jan | commentsIf youaposve ever wanted to test your intelligence, but canapost be bothered to sit through a y IQ test, we may have the perfect solution for you. The worldaposs shortest IQ test is made up of just three maths questions and shouldnapost take too long to complete. But be warned - itaposs pretty tough! Called the Cognitive Reflection Test, the quiz isnapost new, but was originally part of a research paper published in  by MIT professor Shane Frederick. This paper has recently resurfaced online, leaving many keen to give it a go. As part of his research, Professor Frederick had more than , participants from a range of educational backgrounds complete the test - and even those attending top American universities such as Yale and Hard struggled to work out all the answers. Of all those who took part only  percent managed to score three out of three on the test, meaning  percent of people failed - how will you fare   Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Speaking about the test, Professor Frederick, said: The three items on the CRT are aposeasyapos in the sense that their solution is easily understood when explained, yet reaching the correct answer often requires the suppression of an erroneous answer that springs aposimpulsivelyapos to mind. Hereaposs a look at the questions: . A bat and a ball cost . in total. The bat costs  more than the ball. How much does the ball cost  . If it takes five machines five minutes to make five widgets, how long would it take  machines to make  widgets  . In a lake, there is a patch of lily pads. Every day, the patch doubles in size. If it takes  days for the patch to cover the entire lake, how long would it take for the patch to cover half of the lake   These are the three most common answers that people guess - but they are actually incorrect. .  cents .  minutes .  days Professor Frederick adds: Anyone who reflects upon it for even a moment would recognise that the dference between  and  cents is only  cents, not  as the problem stipulates. In this case, catching that error is tantamount to solving the problem, since nearly everyone who does not respond apos centsapos does, in fact give the correct response. The correct answers are: .  cents .  minutes .  days Still puzzled by all of this  Thankfully, Presh Talwalkar, the author of The Hoy of Game Theory: An Introduction to Strategic Thinking explained how to work out the correct answers on his blog, Mind Your Decisions. . Say the ball costs X. Then the bat costs  more, so it is X + . So we have bat + ball  X + . because together they cost .. This means X +   ., then X  ., so X  .. This means the ball costs  cents and the bat costs . . If it takes  machines  minutes to make  widgets, then it takes  machine  minutes to make  widget . If we have  machines working together, then each can make a widget in  minutes. So there will be  widgets in  minutes. . Every day FORWARD the patch doubles in size. So every day BACKWARDS means the patch halves in size. So on day  the lake is half full. How did you do  Let us know in the comments below. news world-news hana-horka-final-moments-folk-"Hana Horka sings with her country band AsonanceByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsHana Horka, a popular Czech folk singer, died last weekend after she caught Covid on purpose because she thought it meant she could avoid having the vaccine and be “free” again. Her son, Jan Rek, lashed out at anti-vaxxers in central Europe for influencing his mother and her decisions. Horka, , was lead singer for Czech folk group Asonance an Jan explained that he and his father, who were both vaccinated, caught Covid over the Christmas holidays. Horka purposely remained in close contact with them both, which led to her catching the virus. Jan also revealed his mother’s final tragic moments before she passed on Sunday. The -year-old remained in good enough health on the morning she died to get dressed for a walk.  But she complained her back was hurting and went to lie down in her bedroom.In an interview with the BBC, Jan said: “In  minutes it was all over. She choked to death.”Horka is thought to have believed thatshe caught the virus, she would not need the vaccine.  Jan explained that while his mother was unvaccinated, she did not subscribe to any of the conspiracy theories around the Covid vaccines. Jan said: “Her philosophy was that she was more OK with the idea of catching Covid than getting vaccinated. Not that we would get microchipped or anything like that.” She celebrated upon learning she had contracted the virus.  Her family said she was “happy” to have Covid because she thought it meant she could obtain a health pass to visit venues those without proof of vaccination or recent recovery are blocked from going to. On her social media just two days before she tragically died, she wrote: “Iaposm very happy about it because in this way I would be able to start having a free le like everyone , and go back to the cinema, on vacation, to take a sauna, to the theater. “I survived… It was intense. So now there will be the theatre, sauna, a concert… and an urgent trip to the sea.”  Jan was left raging with anti-vaxxers in his country who he blamed for her death.On Facebook, following his mother’s death, he wrote: “You took my mother, who based all her arguments on your basis.“I despise you, you are an absolute waste.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Coronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news world-news i-resent-mum-not-switching-"Robin and Gavin speak out after discovering they were switched at birthByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A man who was swapped at birth in South Africa admitted he resents his mum for not switching him back because he grew up poor while the other child was rich. Robin and Gavin were accidentally given to the wrong mothers by a nurse at Nigel Hospital in Johannesburg where they were the only two babies born on that day in February .This meant Robin was raised by single mum Sandy Dawkins who was struggling to get by on the outskirts of Johannesburg while Gavin grew up with wealthier parent Megs Clinton Parker in Pietermaritzburg. The mistake was not uncovered until two years later when a disagreement over Gavinaposs rightful father led to a DNA test revealing that Megs was not his birth mother.  Hospital records further confirmed that Robin was Megsapos biological son who was growing up with Sandy as his mother. When faced with swapping their birth sons back, Megs and Sandy chose to keep the children they had raised since birth. Speaking nearer the time, one of the parents told  Minutes Australia: You canapost reject a child that youaposve been so close to for two years. Initially I think you protect the one youaposve got. The first few days are shock, then the curiosity comes. Whereaposs my baby   The boys grew up km apart in very dferent environments and referred to each other as brothers. But Robin has since admitted that he wishes his biological mother fought to switch him back. Speaking at age , he said he had dficulty accepting the situation and misses his mother Megs awfully a lot who he speaks to daily on the phone.  He told how le with Sandy was not easy and that he resented Gavin who does get things easy. If Iaposve ever wanted something, Iaposve had to work towards it. I’ve never just had it come towards me, he added. At the time, Gavin described being “happy” with the le he was accidentally given and that he did not feel sorry for Robin. He said: “Saying I thank my lucky stars every day would be wrong but at the same time I was given a le which I’ve now lived and I’m still living and I don’t regret anything.  The boysapos mothers embraced one another like sisters after discovering the mistake in  but chose not to swap the boys back. But Megs missed her biological son and encouraged him to move halfway across the country to her home with Gavin in , leaving Sandy without a child. Speaking at the time, Sandy said: “I just want to know she’s really happy with what she’s achieved. “I mean she’s ruined people’s lives, there’s just no other way to look at it… she’s ruined mine for starters.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Single mumSouth AfricaParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: judge bans unvaccinated dad seeing
story: Judge bans unvaccinated dad from seeing -year-old child until he has Covid jabA judge in Quebec, Canada ruled it was not in the best interest for the father to have contact with the child - the mum raised concerns after discovering the father was unvaccinated from his social media postsA dad has been banned from visiting his child unless he gets a Covid- jabImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments An unvaccinated dad has been banned from visiting his child until he gets his Covid- jab.The father was stopped from seeing his child after a judge ruled it was not in the best interest for him to have contact with the -year-old.Superior Court Judge Jean-Sébastien Vaillancourt said that it would normally have been in the best interest of the child to have contact with his father, but not in his best interest to have contact with himhe is not vaccinated and is opposed to health measures in the current epidemiological context, Canadian newspaper Le Devoir reported. His visitation rights have been suspended until February, unless the dad gets vaccinated before then. The judgement came after the dad had requested an extra day with his child over the holiday period, according to local reports in Quebec, Canada.Whose side are you on  Have your say in the comment section The mum contested the request after learning from his social media posts that he was not vaccinated. She further requested a suspension of his visitation rights, claiming he would be a conspirator and anti-vaccine. The child has received both their jabs, but the mum lives with her partner and other children under the age of five who are not yet able to get vaccinated. The judge said: In these circumstances, it is not in the best interests of any of the three children that Monsieur can exercise access toat this time.  for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.This is not the first reported case of a parent being denied visitation for not having their Covid- vaccine. In New York, a dad was banned from visiting his daughter unless he becomes double-jabbed or agrees to weekly Covid tests. The ruling was made by a New York City orce judge, who suspended the parentaposs visitation rights to see the three-year-old girl until he agrees to either option. Matthew Cooper, who is presiding over the estranged coupleaposs orce and custody dispute, wrote in his ruling: “Here, in-person parental access by the defendant is not in the child’s best interests, and there are exceptional circumstances that support its suspension. “The dangers of voluntarily remaining unvaccinated during access with a child while the Covid- virus remains a threat to children’s health and safety cannot be understated. “Unfortunately, and to my mind, incomprehensibly, a sizeable minority, seizing upon misinformation, conspiracy theories, and muddled notions of ‘inidual liberty,’ have refused all entreaties to be vaccinated.” The ruling requires the unnamed dad to either get the jab or present a weekly PCR test in addition to a biweekly antigen test within  hours of a scheduled visit. He currently visits his daughter every other weekend. The judge wrote that the couple split in  and the proceedings have been contentious with the two wrangling over custody of their daughter. The child resides mostly with her mother in Manhattan, where she attends preschool.
